title: The more Trump talks about making trade deals, the more confusing the tariff picture gets
content: The more President Donald Trump talks about his efforts to reach deals with America’s trading partners, the more confusing the tariff picture gets.

title: What world leaders have said about US tariffs — and how negotiations are going with Trump so far
content: Since President Donald Trump's April 2 tariff announcement global leaders have responded with mixed reactions.

title: Avoiding a world trade war
content: We are on the precipice of a world trade war — active and strategic economic diplomacy will be needed to avoid it.
resumen:
The threat of a world trade war due to retaliatory tariffs places the global economic system at risk, while challenging the continuation of a rules-based system and encouraging potentially damaging trade deals. To preserve an open, rules-based system amidst this uncertainty, collective action is needed, led by East Asia and Europe, exemplified by ASEAN's coordinated, non-retaliatory response and continued commitment to multilateral trade norms.

The 28 per cent average tariff rate in the United States today is significantly higher than the average rate of 19.8 per cent imposed during the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930. The highest Smoot-Hawley tariff rate was 59.1 per cent, well below the 145 per cent US President Donald Trump has slapped on all Chinese imports. Today’s tariffs return the United States to its 1821 to 1900 average 29.7 per cent tariff rate.

The retaliatory spiral provoked by the Smoot-Hawley tariffs led to the collapse of global trade from 1929–33, and gave rise to geopolitical tension that brought the World War II several years after. Tariff contagion like that is what’s at risk today: we are on the precipice of a world trade war. Active and strategic economic diplomacy will be needed to avoid that.

The global response to Trump’s Liberation Day tariffs has thus far been, except for China, Canada and Europe, restraint. Europe has temporarily backed away from retaliation because of Trump’s 90 day tariff pause. But more uncertainty is on the way and other countries will be pressured into retaliating like the Chinese and Europeans, do damaging deals with the United States, or join the protectionist game.

The world is about to be rocked by huge flows of trade that are diverted from the United States as well as volatile hot money capital flows, big currency swings and macroeconomic shocks. As Chinese goods face a prohibitive 145 per cent tariff entering the United States, it is likely those products would be flowing other markets.

Chinese products hitting global markets will improve living standards and will relieve inflationary pressures in many countries. But those that compete directly with producing those goods will be tempted to ‘protect’ themselves from what they will see as the dumping of goods on international markets. Tariffs on imports will be the easiest tool for governments to reach for. They are contagious.

The United States has turned its back on the rules-based economic order of which it was the creator and which it underpinned in the post-war era. But the rest of the world does not need to let Trump tear the whole system down. The era of US leadership may be over but the rest of the world has an interest in preserving the global trade order and avoiding a ‘might-is-right’ world of economic disorder. The United States might be the world’s largest economy in market exchange rates and its largest consumer but it now only accounts for 11 per cent of global trade.

What is needed is collective action led by East Asia and Europe — where trade openness is an economic and political security imperative — not against the United States, but to retain the global public good of an open, rules-based economic system.

The response from Southeast Asia has so far been the benchmark. Leaders of ASEAN’s most important economies — Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto, Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, Philippines President Bongbong Marcos and Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong — have coordinated closely around a non-retaliatory response. ASEAN Economic Ministers had already agreed in February to cooperate in the face of looming US tariffs and to avoid protectionist measures against surges of Chinese imports locked out of the US market. The ministers convened a special meeting after the US tariffs were announced and created a taskforce to monitor developments and coordinate collective responses. An ASEAN Leaders’ Meeting has been called for early May. The risks for ASEAN are existential and ASEAN Leaders’ strategy at that point will be globally consequential.

Days before Trump’s Liberation Day tariffs were announced, China, Japan and South Korea’s trade ministers agreed to cooperate on trade and cited East Asia’s Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), that ASEAN created and drives, as a platform from which to do so. ASEAN could call for an ASEAN+3 Leaders’ Meeting with Northeast Asia like they did at the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. But RCEP with Australia and New Zealand would have a better chance of bolstering connections to other Europe and global initiatives. RCEP is the natural platform for projecting and protecting East Asia’s trade and economic interests.

Collective action to preserve the multilateral trading system should come as a priority despite countries negotiating their own deals with the United States. Japan was first in line with Trump himself joining the negotiators last week. The world will be watching closely for Japanese appeasement — moving to managed trade, having the US security blanket contingent on increased purchase and having to boost its defence spending. Bilateral deals with the White House cannot come at the expense of broader interests without triggering multilateral meltdown.

Will any deal struck with this White House, even if it is possible to strike one, be faithfully honoured given the United States has now effectively invalidated every free trade agreement it has ever signed?

The Indonesian delegation led by Economic Minister Airlangga Hartanto successfully met the United States Trade Representative and Secretary of Commerce, but still has no guarantee to receive favourable deal from the United States, even when Indonesia offered various concessions, including to increase imports from the country. As part of reform process, Indonesia seems willing to remove costly local-content requirements and other protectionist measures. But granting US imports preferential access over other imports and granting US companies monopoly power in Indonesian markets will not only be economically damaging, it is seen domestically as political capitulation to a bully. Reforms need to be consistent with the bedrock principle of the multilateral trading system: most-favoured nation or equal treatment.

Southeast Asia’s multilateralist instincts and norms have resulted in the right kind of initial strategic, cooperative reaction. It’s the next step, in negotiating a multilateral course around Trump, that will be decisive to global outcomes.

title: El efecto Trump podría ralentizar el crecimiento de la economía dominicana
content: Las políticas monetarias de Donald Trump en Estados Unidos, podrían provocar que se ralentice el crecimiento de la economía dominicana.
resumen: Las nuevas políticas monetarias ordenadas por Donald Trump en Estados Unidos podrían provocar una moderación en el crecimiento de la economía dominicana. El economista Antonio Ciriaco Cruz, al participar en el Almuerzo Semanal del Grupo de Comunicaciones Corripio, señaló como causas de esa variación tendencial, la incertidumbre que ha generado el incremento de aranceles dispuesto por Trump. La medida impuesta por el presidente estadounidense está ralentizando tradicionales procesos de inversión en el país. República Dominicana comercialmente está integrada a los Estados Unidos, el 50 por ciento de la inversión extranjera proviene de esta nación, y el 68 por ciento de las exportaciones de zona franca son dirigidas a ese mercado. El 85 por ciento de las remesas que llegan al país provienen de ese mercado, así como gran parte de los turistas que visitan el territorio nacional. República Dominicana es de los pocos países que tienen un acuerdo con las dos economías de mayor ingreso en el mundo; Estados Unidos y la Unión Europea. Se mantienen relaciones diplomáticas con China desde el 2018, nación que es el segundo socio en términos de intercambio comercial. El déficit fiscal, según la economista Germania Montás, ronda el 3 por ciento del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB). El 25 por ciento del presupuesto se utiliza para pagar intereses de la deuda, alrededor de un 30 por ciento en remuneraciones del personal público, y un 70 por ciento combinado entre el subsidio eléctrico y directo. La economía dominicana tiene un descenso sostenido de la inversión pública, que representa menos del 9 por ciento del gasto total.

title: What to know about the Fed’s decision.
content: The Federal Reserve stuck to a wait-and-see approach as officials brace for President Trump’s tariffs to stoke higher inflation and slower growth. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said that it’s “not ...
resumen: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged for a third meeting in a row on Wednesday, sticking to a wait-and-see approach amid uncertainty about how significantly President Trump’s tariffs will raise inflation and slow growth. The unanimous decision to stand pat will keep interest rates at 4.25 percent to 4.5 percent. Rates have been there since December after a series of cuts in the second half of 2024. The Fed acknowledged that the labor market was still “solid.” But policymakers also noted that “uncertainty about the economic outlook has increased further” and “risks of higher unemployment and higher inflation have risen.” Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said he could not yet say “which way this will shake out” in terms of whether to be more worried about inflation or growth. He later captured the uncertainty of the moment, saying “It’s really not at all clear what it is we should do.” A 10 percent universal tariff remains in place, along with additional levies on steel, aluminum and cars. The president has also imposed a minimum tariff of 145 percent on Chinese goods. The whiplash has unnerved financial markets, stoking volatility as Wall Street digested the various twists and turns associated with Mr. Trump’s trade policy and his subsequent attacks on Mr. Powell for ignoring his demands to lower interest rates. The central bank is struggling to both assess the economic fallout from Mr. Trump’s policies and game out how it will set monetary policy in an environment in which its goals of maintaining a healthy labor market and keeping inflation low and stable may be in conflict. Officials have grown increasingly worried about how much Mr. Trump’s policies, which also include slashing spending and deporting immigrants, will sap growth. The fear is that the uncertainty will further chill business activity. The Fed is not in a position to respond to early signs that the economy is weakening by preemptively lowering interest rates because of inflation. Market-based measures of inflation expectations suggest that inflation will indeed remain contained after an initial pop. The bar for the central bank to lower interest rates is higher this time. Officials will most likely need to see tangible evidence that the labor market is beginning to weaken before restarting cuts. If monthly jobs growth grinds to a halt, or turns negative, and layoffs rise, that could be enough to bolster the central bank’s conviction that it can begin to reduce rates. Powell said the Fed is not in a hurry to lower interest rates and is going to wait to see the economic effects from Trump’s tariffs before taking any action. With the economy still on solid footing and unemployment low, Fed Chair Powell made clear that there is “no cost” to the Fed taking its time. Powell leaned into the uncertainty of the moment both in terms of how Trump’s tariffs will impact the economy and also how the Fed should react. Powell reiterated that it would be a “difficult judgment” if faced with a situation in which the Fed’s goals of maintaining a healthy labor market and low inflation clash. Powell said the Fed’s policy settings are still restrictive and emphasizes that the Fed is not in a hurry to take action. Powell said the Fed can’t yet say “which way this will shake out” in terms of whether to be more worried about inflation or growth. Powell notes that whether or not tariffs translate into more persistent inflation depends on whether inflation expectations remain “anchored” — that is, whether people expect prices to keep rising. President Trump has been publicly pressuring Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, to lower the rate the central bank controls.

Tensions between the US and China have seen both countries ramp up trade duties upwards of 100 per cent.
US President Donald Trump has repeatedly urged Xi to call him about a potential trade deal.
He oversees US-China economic and trade affairs.
Reuters interviewed 13 foreign investors and diplomats who met with He over the past year.
He is 70 years old.
He has held at least 60 meetings with foreigners in the past year.

He was responsible for formulating industrial policy.

He has supported boosting manufacturing over domestic consumption.
He serves as Xi’s “chief lieutenant for building a trillion-dollar surplus.”
He has brushed off complaints about Chinese overcapacity.
Wen-Ti Sung, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council’s Global China Hub, said that He will be defending China’s trade surplus.
He has been on the frontline of China’s recent outreach to developed markets like Japan and the European Union.
The economic portfolio was previously run by Liu He.
Liu He negotiated a trade agreement with the United States during the first Trump administration.
He has a PhD in economics from Xiamen University.
He should retire in 2027.
He downplayed concerns about Beijing’s rare earth export controls and the safety of Japanese nationals in China.
He rose through the local bureaucracy in his native Fujian province.
Xi built his power base as a local official in the 1990s and early 2000s.
He became a trusted lieutenant of Xi around that time.
He was transferred to the industrial port city of Tianjin in 2009.
He was nicknamed “He the Demolisher” by locals.

title: Trump tariffs could make Americans pay $123B more annually for 10 common gadgets
content: China has finally agreed to open negotiations with the Trump administration as the tech industry warns that tariffs could soon spike Americans' costs for the 10 most popular consumer technology ...
resumen: China has agreed to open negotiations with the Trump administration. Tariffs could soon spike Americans' costs for the 10 most popular consumer technology products by more than $123 billion annually. He Lifeng, China’s lead on China-US economic and trade affairs, will meet with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent from May 9 to 12 to open talks. The US must "demonstrate sincerity" and come ready to "correct its wrongdoings," including facing "the severe negative impacts of its unilateral tariff measures on itself and the world." Trump raised tariffs on some Chinese imports as high as 145 percent. Americans risk paying much higher prices for any Chinese imports that are not exempted from those 145 percent tariffs. They also face potentially higher prices from other tariffs the Trump administration imposed, including a baseline 10 percent tariff on all imports from all countries and reciprocal tariffs that kick in July, which would add an additional 11 to 50 percent tax on all imports from 57 countries. Non-exempted video game consoles could soon cost more than $1,000 on average, up by about 69 percent. Headphones costing Americans up to $5 more or speakers costing up to $60 more could drain wallets nationwide by more than $2.5 billion. An estimated 11 percent increase on imports of non-exempt China-made TVs could significantly hurt the US economy by "forcing consumers to pay $1.9 billion more than they otherwise would for the televisions they continue to buy." Buyers of smartphones, laptops and tablets, and connected devices would likely feel the greatest impact. In 2023, China accounted for 87 percent of video game consoles, 78 percent of smartphones, 79 percent of laptops and tablets, and 67 percent of monitors imported into the US. Laptops could soon cost more than $1,000, tablets nearly $600, and smartphones nearly $1,100, while connected devices could cost up to 22 percent more. Trump's tariff regime threatens to "shrink the US economy by $69 billion annually" from price shifts of just 10 popular tech products. The CTA has been advocating on Capitol Hill for more exemptions. Consumers would lose about $16 in spending power for every $1 gained by domestic producers. The CTA is already forecasting drastic drops in consumption of video game consoles (down by up to 73 percent), laptops and tablets (45 percent), and smartphones (nearly 50 percent). For low-income families, the smartphone price hikes could hit the hardest. Apple recently estimated that tariffs could add $900 million in costs in this quarter alone. South Korea-based Samsung—which has a Vietnamese production hub subject to 46 percent tariffs. Nvidia, AMD, Super Micro, and Marvell have warned investors of potentially billions in lost revenue.

title: Fed holds rates steady, warns of stagflation risks
content: Fed officials opted Wednesday to hold interest rates steady as President Donald Trump’s tariffs unsettle the US economy.
resumen: The Federal Reserve (Fed) decided to hold its benchmark interest rate steady, keeping it at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%. The Fed's statement included a warning about rising risks of higher unemployment and higher inflation, signaling concerns about stagflation. The Fed is monitoring the economic impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the Fed does not need to rush to adjust rates and that there is a "great deal of uncertainty" about the implications of Trump’s tariff policy. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note edged lower to 4.28%. The US dollar slightly strengthened against other major currencies. Traders expect a 76.8% chance the Fed holds rates steady again at its next decision in June. Powell said the outcome of trade talks could "materially" change the economic picture. Powell said the Fed has limited tools to address supply chain problems. Powell declined to say the Fed will lower rates this year, blaming Trump's tariffs. Powell said the central bank may have been “a little late” to begin lowering rates. The Federal Reserve received criticism for waiting until September’s monetary policy meeting last year to begin cutting interest rates for the first time since 2020. The Federal Reserve’s latest policy statement noted that the risk of higher unemployment and higher inflation have both risen. The Fed’s decision to keep rates unchanged for the third meeting in a row was unanimous. The US economy is beginning to show the effects of President Donald Trump’s haphazard trade war. The Dow closed higher by 285 points, or 0.7%. The S&P 500 gained 0.43%. The Nasdaq Composite gained 0.27%. Consumer sentiment is falling, and businesses are concerned about hiring and investing due to tariffs. The Federal Reserve is in a bind with concerns about inflation and an economic slump, which will lead to higher unemployment. President Donald Trump signaled that the 145% tariff he placed on most imports from China is here to stay. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said some of the 18 trade deals being considered are in “quite advanced” stages. The unemployment rate in April held steady at 4.2% and employers added a surprisingly strong 177,000 new jobs. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to announce Wednesday it is keeping interest rates unchanged for the third time in a row.

title: Trump’s Threatened Tariffs Are So Large, 10% Feels Like a Relief
content: The statement refers to the 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump put in place on most U.S. imports one month ago. Such a significant increase in U.S. tariffs would have been unthinkable a few years ago.
resumen:
There has been a mantra spreading among weary corporate executives: Ten percent is the new zero.

The statement refers to the 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump put in place on most U.S. imports one month ago.

Mr. Trump’s “Liberation Day” announcement on April 2 that he was planning tariffs of 10 percent to 60 percent on dozens of America’s trading partners set off a rout in the bond markets and a flight from the U.S. dollar.

Mr. Trump also ratcheted up tariffs on China to a minimum of 145 percent amid a trade spat with Beijing.

The president quickly paused tariffs on most countries, giving them 90 days to negotiate trade deals instead.

Mr. Trump also granted a lucrative exemption from China tariffs for makers of electronics and offered some limited relief for automakers.

Investors have lapped up any signs of good news.

Stock markets have now regained nearly all of the losses they sustained after April 2.

The United States still has a 10 percent “universal” tariff in effect on most imports globally, as well as 25 percent tariffs on imported cars, metals and goods from Canada and Mexico.

Overall, according to the Budget Lab at Yale, consumers face an average effective tariff rate of 28 percent, the highest since 1901.

For some companies, tariffs of 10 to 25 percent are still enough to erase profit margins, stall expansion or hiring plans or even push them out of business.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has warned that many small businesses in particular might not survive.

Jane Fraser, the chief executive of Citigroup, said companies could withstand lower tariffs, though trade uncertainty had forced them to pause investment and hiring.

Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, would meet with Chinese officials this weekend in Geneva.

The administration might choose to quickly drop some of its tariffs on China as a good-will gesture once the countries restart negotiations — but tariffs have risen so much that the United States might have to cut them by more than 100 percentage points to meaningfully restart trade.

In a post on Truth Social on Sunday, Mr. Trump proposed adding 100 percent tariffs to movies produced outside the country.

On Monday, the president said that tariffs on pharmaceuticals would be coming in the next few weeks and that he had already decided on the rate.

Maros Sefcovic, the European Union’s commissioner for trade, said that “more U.S. tariff actions could well be on their way,” pointing to investigations into lumber, pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, critical minerals and trucks.

If all those investigations led to tariffs, he said, 97 percent of E.U. exports to the United States would be subject to taxes.

title: Trump Says U.S. Won’t Drop Tariffs Ahead of China Talks
content: The Treasury secretary and trade representative plan to meet with Chinese officials this weekend to discuss trade and economic matters.
resumen:
El presidente Trump dijo el miércoles que no reduciría los altos aranceles sobre los bienes de China antes de las conversaciones de este fin de semana entre funcionarios estadounidenses y chinos, a pesar de las solicitudes de Beijing para que lo hiciera.

Preguntado por los reporteros en la Oficina Oval si reduciría los aranceles sobre las exportaciones chinas, que ahora son de un mínimo del 145 por ciento, para iniciar las conversaciones, el Sr. Trump fue conciso: "No".

También insinuó que los chinos habían sido los que solicitaron las conversaciones comerciales, contradiciendo las declaraciones de China de que las dos partes se reunían a petición de los estadounidenses. "Creo que deberían volver y estudiar sus archivos", dijo el presidente.

Scott Bessent, el secretario del Tesoro, y Jamieson Greer, el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, planean reunirse con funcionarios chinos el sábado y el domingo en Ginebra para discutir asuntos comerciales y económicos. Los países han estado estancados. Los altos aranceles han estado perjudicando a las empresas de ambos países, pero ninguno de los gobiernos ha querido parecer que está cediendo al otro al solicitar una reunión.

Funcionarios chinos dicen que tienen poca claridad por parte de Estados Unidos sobre qué cambios de política podrían apaciguar al Sr. Trump, y no está claro si los dos países llegarán a algún tipo de acuerdo comercial.

El miércoles, el Sr. Trump dijo que China necesitaría "dejar de importar fentanilo", y culpó al ex presidente Joseph R. Biden Jr. por no cumplir un acuerdo que el Sr. Trump firmó con China durante su primer mandato.

El Sr. Trump habló desde la Oficina Oval mientras juramentaba a David Perdue, el nuevo embajador en China. El Sr. Perdue, ex senador de Georgia, también es ex director ejecutivo de Reebok y Dollar General, y la comunidad empresarial lo ha visto como alguien que podría ser una fuerza moderadora en la relación entre Estados Unidos y China.

"Lo elegí hace mucho tiempo, pero simplemente sucedió que llegó en una fecha bastante importante", dijo el presidente.

title: China Agreed to U.S. Tariff Talks but Is Likely to Play Hardball
content: Beijing says it will meet with American officials to discuss trade, but warned Washington against using the engagement to ratchet up pressure on China.
resumen:
China is seeking to cast itself as the responsible one in a bruising superpower competition by agreeing to meet with the Trump administration to discuss trade.

China had publicly said that it would not engage in trade talks with the United States under duress, refusing to “kneel down” and compromise with a “bully.” It insisted that Washington should first drop its eye-watering tariffs on China as a condition for negotiations.

Beijing indicated it would come to the table after all, saying that its top trade official, He Lifeng, would meet with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent in Switzerland this week. It maintained a tough stance, warning Washington against using the talks as “a smoke screen to continue coercion and extortion.”

The Chinese government said it had come to this decision “based on a full consideration of global expectations, China’s interests and the calls of American industry and consumers.”

Yun Sun, a China analyst at the Stimson Center, said, “China is trying to frame itself as the responsible party, but it’s still a pretty hard-line tone: You better behave yourself in these talks.”

Economic data has shown that the trade brinkmanship was taking a toll on both countries’ economies.

The Trump administration’s decision to raise tariffs on Chinese goods imported to the United States by 145 percent, and China’s response in hiking its own tariffs on American goods to 125 percent, has effectively frozen all trade between the two countries in recent weeks.

Chinese factories were hit with the steepest slowdown in activity in more than a year, and shipments of Chinese goods to the United States have plunged, triggering a wave of warnings from retailers about shortages. The American economy shrank in the first three months of the year, and companies slashed growth forecasts.

Mr. Bessent said the talks with China were more likely to be aimed at de-escalating trade tensions than reaching a deal.

Mr. Bessent said he expected the meeting with Chinese officials in Switzerland to focus on de-escalation rather than any major deal.

China wants to show that it will be coming to the negotiations from a position of strength, even though the U.S. had not canceled tariffs first as Beijing had demanded. In recent days it has repeatedly said that U.S. officials had reached out for talks and that it was considering the request.

Ms. Sun said, “The Chinese are trying to avoid the image that the Chinese were eager to talk.”

Chinese officials will likely be treating the trade talks as a fact-finding mission.

Wang Xiangwei, an associate professor of journalism at Hong Kong Baptist University, said, “The Chinese want to find out what Donald Trump is really up to, and you can only get this by engaging in direct talks.”

Peter Navarro, a senior White House trade adviser, has defended the tariffs as necessary, while Mr. Bessent has said the U.S. is willing to negotiate with countries.

Mr. Bessent said on Fox News that the talks would be held on Saturday and Sunday.

China said Mr. He was going to be in Geneva from Friday to Monday for meetings with Swiss leaders and that while he was there he would also meet Mr. Bessent. The Trump administration said Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, would also attend the meetings, though China did not mention Mr. Greer in its own statements about the talks.

China has also been trying to persuade other countries not to cave to pressure from the Trump administration’s efforts to isolate China by imposing tariffs of their own on Chinese products, or by decoupling from Chinese manufacturing.

Chinese officials have been under pressure at home from the fallout of both a multiyear property crisis that has wiped out the savings of many families, along with broader trade tensions with countries other than the United States.

China’s central bank and its financial regulators on Wednesday took their biggest policy steps yet to shield the economy from the trade war, moving to shore up the economy with a series of steps to make it easier for banks to lend money and get people spending.

Wu Qing, China’s stock regulator, said, “The Trump administration’s “tariff policies have dealt a severe blow to the international economic and trade order, triggered significant turbulence in international financial markets, and placed considerable pressure on the domestic capital market.”

The Chinese side also comes to the talks emboldened by the knowledge that Mr. Trump has blinked in the face of a sharp sell-off in U.S. government bond markets, and broader financial market turbulence. The midterm elections in the United States could exert some pressure on Mr. Trump to lower or cut tariffs if consumer prices rise as a result of a shortage of goods.

Scott Kennedy, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said, “If they totally stonewall the Trump administration, they could end up looking complicit in bringing the global economy to a halt.”

title: EU prepares Boeing and auto tariffs as Trump trade truce teeters
content: Brussels to unveil countermeasures targeting $100bn in US goods if talks fail; aerospace braces for renewed tariff war The European Union will unveil retaliatory trade measures on Thursday targeting ...
resumen:
The European Union will unveil retaliatory trade measures on Thursday targeting nearly €100 billion (US$113 billion) worth of US goods—including Boeing aircraft and American-made cars—should ongoing negotiations with Washington collapse, Trade Commissioner Maroš Šefčovič confirmed on Wednesday.

The measures would revive and expand the EU’s previously suspended rebalancing tariffs. That list had initially covered €21 billion in US exports, with 25% duties aimed at products such as steel, aluminium, and motorcycles.

President Donald Trump has imposed a 25% tariff on European cars and metals, alongside a “reciprocal” 10% duty on almost all EU goods—a figure that could double to 20% if no deal is reached by the July 8 expiry of a 90-day tariff pause.

Boeing aircraft are reportedly among the top targets. The US exported over US$35 billion in aerospace goods to Europe last year.

Ryanair CEO Michael O’Leary last week warned that the Irish airline could cancel a $33 billion Boeing order if tariffs materially raise prices.

Šefčovič also said Brussels may pursue legal remedies through the World Trade Organization, labelling the US tariffs “simply unjust, unfair, and in total breach of international commercial law.”

The EU is aiming to end all gas imports from Russia by 2027.

title: Steve Chapman: President Donald Trump’s policies are an education in folly
content: This clownfest dramatizes something Americans had but didn’t appreciate: a functioning system administered by people with experience.
resumen:
Donald Trump's policies are serving the unintended purpose of generating wisdom among the American people. He is teaching the value of some previously underappreciated assets by depriving us of them.

The first is free trade. Trump's embrace of high tariffs is reminding both consumers and business people of the benefits of access to everything other nations have to offer. The duties will gouge Americans on cars, food, appliances, electronics, furniture, clothing and — well, nearly everything. They would also decimate U.S. industries, many of which use imported parts and material in their own products. A recent Washington Post-ABC-Ipsos poll found that 64% disapprove of Trump’s tariff policies.

The second is capable government. Ineptitude, arrogance and disdain for expertise have been the signature of Trump’s Cabinet. Trump’s Department of Government Efficiency is a manifestation of right-wing contempt for federal programs and employees. Musk boasted that he would cut federal spending by $2 trillion, a figure he later reduced to $1 trillion, and then $150 billion — a largely fictitious figure. The libertarian Cato Institute agrees that “Elon and DOGE are failing to meet their objective to deliver major spending cuts.” Americans will not be so blase when mass firings at the Social Security Administration, the Internal Revenue Service and the Department of Veterans Affairs make it harder to get benefits they are entitled to. Yosemite National Park in California saw its only locksmith fired; a court later ordered his reinstatement.

Finally, there is due process. Trump and his accomplices claim the right to deport foreigners to a brutal prison in El Salvador without giving them any opportunity to challenge the grounds for their removal. Mahmoud Khalil, a legal resident who had been convicted of no crime, was among the victims. A Washington Post-ABC-Ipsos poll found that a majority of Americans reject the policy of “sending undocumented immigrants who are suspected of being members of a criminal group to a prison in El Salvador without a court hearing.”

title: Trump’s lifelong belief in tariffs is about to face its acid test
content: President Donald Trump’s faith in tariffs is undimmed by a dose of negative US growth and signs of a looming supply crunch.
resumen: President Donald Trump's lifelong belief that tariffs can make the United States richer by forcing other nations to bend to his demands is being reinforced by the early skirmishes in his trade wars. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will meet with Chinese officials this weekend in Switzerland. The talks, which will also include US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, represent the most critical moment in the trade wars so far. Trump’s strategy and rhetoric in recent days are likely to complicate Bessent’s assignment, since the president is showing that his faith in tariffs is undimmed by a dose of negative US growth and signs of a looming supply crunch. Trump said of Chinese leaders in the Oval Office on Tuesday, “They want to meet… by not trading, we’re losing nothing.” Trump’s statements suggest that tariffs may not be the means to an end, but the end itself. The administration has yet to announce any new breakthroughs, so there is no real prospect of tariffs being lifted any time soon. Trump’s volatility and record of changing his mind on a dime mean that none of his statements should ever be regarded as definitive. The talks with China will be key to establishing whether a soft landing is possible for the trade wars. Bessent told Fox News on Tuesday that his initial plan is to try to cool the confrontation and that the talks with Chinese officials represent the “missing piece” in the administration’s strategy. China typically favors intricate trade talks that play out for months. A growing number of Trump’s comments and social media posts suggest that he’s not yet interested in changing course a third of the way through a 90-day pause in reciprocal tariffs. On Tuesday, he played down expectations for a flurry of trade deals that he and senior aides had been predicting were imminent for days. Trump said, “So, I wish they’d keep — you know, stop asking, ‘How many deals are you signing this week?’ Because one day, we’ll come and we’ll give you a hundred deals.” Trump’s preferred outcome of the trade deals may be permanent protectionism. Trump explained his vision of operating as a retailer who sets the price for each individual customer. In this scenario, tariffs are not an attempt to draw countries into talks to unlock acceptable deals for both sides. Instead, they are a way to fix a levy for the right to do business with the US that would depend on how far each nation sacrifices their own economic interests to boost America’s. Trump said, “Think of us as a super-luxury store, a store that has the goods. You’re going to come and you’re going to pay a price, and we’re going to give you a very good price.” Trump also said last month that his 145% tariff on China will “come down come down substantially, but it won’t be zero.” He told Time Magazine in a recent interview that he’d consider it a “total victory” if tariffs are at 50%. The days of untamed globalization are over. He wants to transform it so that the US becomes a manufacturing and exporting giant but doesn’t buy things from abroad. Trump said, “They have to sign deals with us… We don’t care about their market. They want a piece of our market.” Trump’s comments on trade alongside Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney offered a striking glimpse into how he thinks. Having a president set the price of access to the US market would be an extraordinary way to run a 21st-century economy. Trump has a foggy understanding of how tariffs work. Attempts to artificially control the price of goods usually causes shortages and supply chain issues, and they can spike inflation. Trump has already granted temporary tariffs carve-outs on some tech products, including iPhones, and to parts manufacturers that supply the auto industry after lobbying from CEOs. Trump said Tuesday, “We don’t want steel from Canada ‘cause we’re making our own steel… We really don’t want Canadian steel and we don’t want Canadian aluminum and various other things because we want to be able to do it ourself.” Trump is envisioning a real attempt to drive other nations out of business to make them dependent on America. Trump said, “We don’t really want cars from Canada. And we’ve put tariffs on cars from Canada, and at a certain point, it won’t make economic sense for Canada to build those cars.” Trump said, “We’ve been ripped off by everybody for 50 years, for 50 years, and we’re just not going to do that anymore. We can’t do that, and we can’t let any country do that to us.”

title: US Fed holds rates steady despite Trump's pressure, flags rising inflation and job market risks
content: The Fed kept its rate at 4.3% for the third straight meeting, after cutting it three times in a row at the end of last year.
resumen: The US Federal Reserve kept its key interest rate unchanged Wednesday (May 7), brushing off President Donald Trump’s demands to lower borrowing costs, and said that the risks of higher unemployment and higher inflation have risen. The Federal Reserve held its benchmark interest rate steady at 4.3% for the third consecutive meeting, following three straight cuts late last year. Economists and Wall Street investors still anticipate two to three rate reductions in 2025. Sweeping tariffs introduced by President Trump have created significant uncertainty around the US economic outlook and the Fed’s next moves. The import duties could drive up inflation by making imported goods and components more costly, while also triggering job losses as businesses face higher input costs and scale back operations. The Fed’s goals are to keep prices stable and maximise employment. At a press conference after the release of the policy statement, Powell repeatedly said the current policy rate puts Fed officials in a good position to “wait and see” what the ultimate impacts of the tariffs are. Powell said, there’s too much uncertainty to say how the Fed will react.

title: EJ ANTONI: Trump’s Labor Market Is Healthy, But There Are Warnings Signs
content: While the mainstream media talking heads pontificate about Trump’s economy being in freefall, the labor market just keeps moving along.
resumen: The April jobs report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows solid growth, with 177,000 payrolls added, though previous months were revised down to 119,000 additional payrolls. The survey of households showed the number of people employed jumped 436,000 for the month. More than half a million people joined the labor force. The employment-to-population ratio and the labor force participation rate both rose. Nearly all the rise in payrolls came from the productive private sector. The federal government, excluding the postal service, saw its fourth monthly decrease in payrolls. Within the private sector, the job gains were widespread across most industries with two-thirds of all jobs added over the last year now being full-time work. The number of multiple jobholders declined. The manufacturing sector saw hiring grind to a halt in April, causing the sector to lose about 1,000 jobs. The subsectors that caused the decline were semiconductors and automotive. The administration's narrative is all over the place between Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, and Senior Counselor Peter Navarro. The surge in imports created the most lopsided quarter of international trade ever, which in turn reduced economic growth by a record 4.83 percentage points, as measured by gross domestic product. E.J. Antoni, Ph.D., is a public finance economist, the Richard F. Aster fellow at the Heritage Foundation, and a senior fellow at Unleash Prosperity.

title: American car, made in Korea: Why GM gets roiled by tariffs
content: Long gone are the days when an imported car meant a foreign car. And no company proves the point more than General Motors Co.
resumen:
General Motors Co. imported more cars into the U.S. last year than any other automaker, with nearly half of the 1.23 million autos GM sold in the U.S. built abroad, including Korean-made Chevrolet Trax and Buick Envista SUVs.

U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed 25% tariffs on imported autos, potentially costing GM up to US$5 billion this year, which could slash 2025 earnings before interest and taxes by about 20%.

Ford Motor Co. faces a $2.5 billion tariff hit this year.

GM shares have fallen more than 14% this year.

GM will use cost cuts to offset 30% of its tariff impact.

GM operates three factories in South Korea.

Mary Barra, GM’s chief executive officer, mentioned ongoing discussions with key trade partners.

GM, Ford and Chrysler-parent Stellantis NV combined to import 2.2 million cars into the U.S. last year.

Trump agreed to phase in tariffs on auto parts over two years and exempted them from paying additional levies on materials such as steel and aluminum.

Stellantis imports about 44% of the Chryslers, Dodges, Jeeps and Rams it sells in the U.S.

Ford relies on imports for about 21% of its domestic sales.

Cars made in Korea bear the full brunt of the 25% tariffs, accounting for $2 billion of GM’s import exposure.

GM imported nearly 55,000 cars last year from China, which now face a tariff of 145%.

GM’s history in Korea dates back more than 50 years.

The Chevrolet Trailblazer starts under $25,000.

title: Are U.S. Tariffs Affecting Your Business? We Want to Hear From You.
content: The New York Times wants to hear from European business owners about how they are navigating the uncertainty of President Trump’s tariffs.
resumen:
President Trump’s trade war has created chaos for companies around the world. After announcing tariffs that started at 20 percent for nearly all imports from European Union members — and more on other countries — the president has scaled the rate to 10 percent until July, saying his administration will use the time to negotiate bilateral deals with America’s trading partners. At the same time, Mr. Trump has escalated a trade war with China, potentially squeezing European companies.

To better understand the impact the tariffs are having on companies in Europe, including Britain, we would like to hear from business owners, entrepreneurs, managers and employees. How might the import taxes affect your company or job? Have you delayed hiring, postponed expansion plans or canceled orders? Have you altered your supply chains? We would also like to hear what tariffs mean for your production, and whether you are considering moving some part of it to the United States.

We will read every response and reach out if we are interested in learning more. We won’t publish any part of your response without contacting you first and obtaining your consent. Your contact information will not be shared outside The Times newsroom and we will use it only to get in touch with you.

title: Ex-Rep to MAGA billionaire: Trump wants his ass kissed and ‘it’s not going to happen’
content: MAGA billionaire Kevin O’Leary says he’s blocking out all of the “noise and bluster” about “pencils and dolls” from doomsday critics who insist that Donald Trump’s unnecessary trade wars soon will ...
resumen:
MAGA billionaire Kevin O’Leary says he’s blocking out all of the “noise and bluster” about “pencils and dolls” from doomsday critics who insist that Donald Trump’s unnecessary trade wars soon will throw gasoline on smoldering inflation, while producing empty shelves, layoffs and likely a recession.

O’Leary predicted “100%” that the Trump administration will get trade deals done with America’s top partners — Canada, Mexico, the European Union, Switzerland, Italy and India — within the next four or five months.

Former Democratic New Jersey Congressman Tom Malinowski, who appeared with O’Leary on CNN, smirked.

Malinowski said: “Trump said, ‘This will be easy,’ just as he said that solving the Ukraine war will be easy. ‘We’ll do it on the first day. Solving the Gaza war will be easy. [Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu] will just do what I ask him to do. ‘I’ll impose tariffs on every country in the world, and before long, every single one of them will be begging me, will be coming to the White House to kiss my ass.’ And it hasn’t happened. It’s not going to happen. One reason it’s not going to happen is because ... the most popular thing to be in the world right now is a leader who stands up to Donald Trump. And that’s not a situation that’s conducive to these countries compromising with us on trade or anything else. “So, you know, maybe if we’re looking for meaningful deals, it could take a year. It could take two years. The American economy does not have that time. Small business people don’t have that amount of time. Truck drivers don’t have that amount of time. Consumers who worry about inflation don’t have that amount of time.”

When Trump first announced his tariff plans, O’Leary — a huge Trump supporter — said, “I would like to go to DEFCON 1 with China, tariffs 400 percent, I brought it up, bring the supreme leader to Washington, or crush his economy until he has riots in the streets for food.”

On Tuesday, Trump’s tense meeting with Canada Prime Minister Mark Carney ended without trade deal.

title: En China, los aranceles ponen a las fábricas de ropa en una encrucijada
content: Al terminar una laguna fiscal estadounidense, los fabricantes de ropa que venden a Estados Unidos se ven obligados a considerar mercados alternativos o ubicaciones más baratas dentro y fuera de ...
resumen:
Al terminar una laguna fiscal estadounidense, los fabricantes de ropa que venden a Estados Unidos se ven obligados a considerar mercados alternativos o ubicaciones más baratas dentro y fuera de China.

Liu Miao ha vendido ropa en Amazon a compradores mayoristas de Estados Unidos durante los últimos cinco años. Ese comercio se ha interrumpido bruscamente.

Liu es propietario de una pequeña fábrica en Cantón, que ha sido durante mucho tiempo el centro de la competitiva industria china de confección de ropa. Él y otros gerentes de fábrica, que ya lidiaban con márgenes de ganancia estrechos, dijeron la semana pasada que la combinación de los aranceles y el nuevo impuesto del presidente Donald Trump sobre las importaciones baratas había afectado profundamente sus negocios. Los costos a lo largo de la cadena de suministro también son más elevados.

Los aranceles han hecho imposible que Liu siga vendiendo en Amazon, donde antes ganaba alrededor de 1 dólar por cada prenda, pero ahora solo obtiene 50 centavos. Y sentía que no podía recortar el salario de sus empleados, dijo Liu. “Ahora mismo no se puede vender nada a Estados Unidos”, dijo Liu. “Los aranceles son demasiado altos”.

Plataformas como Amazon, Shein y Temu llevaron la vasta cadena de suministro manufacturero de China a las puertas del mundo. Estos mercados en línea hicieron posible que miles de pequeñas fábricas de Cantón llegaran a compradores de Estados Unidos. Y como los paquetes de menos de 800 dólares podían entrar en Estados Unidos libres de impuestos, las fábricas y, a su vez, las plataformas pudieron cobrar precios muy bajos.

Las exportaciones han sido uno de los principales motores del crecimiento económico de China en los últimos años. Los negocios han ido especialmente bien en el comercio electrónico.

Pero ahora que las tensiones comerciales han obligado a las dos mayores economías del mundo a separarse, muchas empresas de Cantón se enfrentan a un punto de inflexión.

Los aranceles agravan los diversos problemas a los que se enfrentan los fabricantes de ropa. Cada vez es más difícil obtener ganancias ya que el gobierno chino ha tenido dificultades para conseguir que los consumidores gasten más tras el hundimiento del mercado inmobiliario del país. Sin el aumento del valor de la vivienda, muchas personas chinas restringen su gasto.

Esto perjudicó los negocios de Zhang Chen, quien poseía seis tiendas de ropa en la provincia central de Hubei. Pero cuando los compradores no volvieron tras la pandemia de covid y los alquileres se mantuvieron altos, decidió cerrarlas todas.

“En 2020, el negocio no se recuperaba, y en 2021, seguía sin hacerlo. En 2022, cuando seguía igual, parecía que no iba a recuperarse nunca”, dijo Zhang. Ahora gana unos 100 dólares al día entregando prendas recién cosidas en los puntos de recolección de Shein, cerca del aeropuerto.

Las fábricas de Cantón no son los talleres automatizados que producen vehículos eléctricos ni los campus de fabricación de semiconductores que son clave en el esfuerzo que China lleva años realizando para garantizar su resistencia geopolítica mediante la tecnología avanzada. Sin embargo, las fábricas de ropa de China emplean a millones de trabajadores que se afanan por ganarse la vida.

En entrevistas, nueve propietarios y gerentes de fábricas de Cantón dijeron que estaban considerando la posibilidad de trasladar sus operaciones, algunas a provincias como Hubei, a unos 960 kilómetros de distancia, donde podrían pagar a los trabajadores salarios más bajos. Unos pocos propietarios dijeron que posiblemente se trasladarían a países como Vietnam, donde se han establecido muchas fábricas chinas para evitar posibles nuevos aranceles, tan elevados como los que ya se aplican a las exportaciones de China.

Muchos informaron de una disminución de los pedidos. Otros dijeron que habían suspendido algunas líneas de producción. Todos describieron haber visto cómo las empresas vecinas cerraban sus puertas en los últimos meses.

El viernes, cuando entró en vigor la política estadounidense de poner fin a las importaciones libres de impuestos procedentes de China, Liu Bin cerró su extensa fábrica de prendas de vestir, donde montones de paquetes de Shein se agolpaban contra las ventanas.

La fábrica de Liu se especializa en vestidos y tops pensados para llevar a una fiesta en la playa o a una cita nocturna, y Shein suele comprarle unas 100.000 piezas al mes. Pero en abril, después de que la empresa le encargara la mitad de eso, empezó a trasladar su línea de producción a la provincia vecina de Jiangxi. Ya no podía pagar el alquiler en Cantón.

Liu dijo que Shein ofrecía incentivos para ayudar a cubrir el costo de trasladar las operaciones a Vietnam, y él lo había considerado, “pero entonces los aranceles en Vietnam también se hicieron aún más altos”.

Dijo que también había intentado encontrar compradores en TikTok y Temu, pero los pedidos habían bajado en todas las plataformas. “Todos están cayendo, y nosotros solo esperamos y observamos”, dijo Liu.

Temu dijo el viernes que había dejado de enviar productos de China directamente a compradores de Estados Unidos.

Dado que los consumidores chinos son prudentes a la hora de gastar, a las fábricas les resultará difícil vender en su país tanto como exportaban.

El gobierno chino ha estado animando a las plataformas nacionales de comercio electrónico a ayudar a las pequeñas empresas a vender a su mercado nacional. Pero, dado que los consumidores chinos son prudentes a la hora de gastar, a las fábricas les resultará difícil vender en el país tanto como exportaban.

Han Junxiu, quien vende calcetines novedosos en Shein y Temu, dijo que dudaba que el gobierno estadounidense súbitamente pudiera empezar a cobrar aranceles sobre los paquetes de bajo precio, los cuales habían estado entrando en Estados Unidos a un ritmo de cuatro millones al día.

“No creo que sea tan realista”, dijo Han tras cerrar su puesto por la noche en la Feria de Cantón, la feria anual de exportación de la provincia.

Este es exactamente el tipo de cosas que los estadounidenses seguirán necesitando comprar a las empresas chinas, dijo Han. “¿Dónde más van a comprar todo esto?”, preguntó.

content: A un mes de que los Estados Unidos impusiera un 10 % de arancel a los productos dominicanos como parte de su nueva política comercial, el intercambio entre ambos países fluctúa con normalidad, pese a ...
resumen:
A un mes de que Estados Unidos impusiera un 10 % de arancel a los productos dominicanos, el intercambio entre ambos países fluctúa con normalidad.

El ministro de Industria, Comercio y Mipymes (MICM), Víctor -Ito- Bisonó, informó que se terminó un documento que se le remitirá a Estados Unidos para iniciar las revisiones.

El reporte a entregar resume, en diez puntos clave, cómo el arancel afecta a la República Dominicana y propone un plan de trabajo para lograr el desmonte de ese 10 % de arancel, de acuerdo al vicepresidente de la Asociación de Industrias de la República Dominicana (AIRD), Mario Pujols.

Las zonas francas, el sector industrial y el sector comercial siguen siendo los más afectados hasta el momento.

El vicepresidente ejecutivo del Consejo Nacional de la Empresa Privada (Conep), César Dargam, dijo que se está trabajando con el Gobierno, subiendo todos los insumos de los sectores sensibles, el impacto que pueda tener y empujando a que se pueda mantener el diálogo bilateral con los Estados Unidos.

El diálogo pudiera tomar desde semanas hasta meses, según las fuentes consultadas.

Bisonó precisó que Estados Unidos aún no ha definido si su nueva política arancelaria se aplicará de forma unilateral, por grupos, por regiones o por tamaño de economía.

Dargam señaló que hay un canal de comunicación abierto y habrán más reuniones en los próximos días.

title: Hollywood bajo lupa: ¿Qué significan las nuevas políticas de Donald Trump para el cine latino?
content: Los países latinoamericanos han sido históricamente proveedores de locaciones exóticas, equipos técnicos calificados y mano de obra barata para producciones extranjeras ...
resumen: Durante los primeros 100 días del segundo mandato de Donald Trump, la industria del entretenimiento respiraba con alivio. Las películas, clasificadas como servicios y no como bienes tangibles, quedaron fuera de los aranceles iniciales del “Día de la Liberación”. En una publicación en su red social, el presidente anunció que Hollywood está en la mira. Trump escribió: “La industria cinematográfica en América está MURIENDO rápidamente” y agregó: “Otros países están ofreciendo todo tipo de incentivos para atraer a nuestros cineastas y estudios fuera de Estados Unidos… Esto es una amenaza a la seguridad nacional”. Este cambio de tono tiene implicaciones geopolíticas, culturales y comerciales que trascienden las fronteras estadounidenses y representa una oportunidad (y un riesgo) crucial para el cine latinoamericano. La postura de Trump parece estar motivada por dos grandes temores: la fuga de talentos y producción hacia países con mayores incentivos fiscales y la pérdida del “poder blando” estadounidense. Si los grandes estudios empiezan a trasladar más producciones fuera de EE.UU. por razones fiscales, legales o políticas, las industrias cinematográficas de otros países podrían vivir un auge. Latinoamérica, con una infraestructura creciente, talento probado y costos más bajos, entra en escena. Los países latinoamericanos han sido históricamente proveedores de locaciones exóticas, equipos técnicos calificados y mano de obra barata para producciones extranjeras. El nuevo escenario internacional podría cambiar las reglas del juego. Si las producciones estadounidenses enfrentan barreras fiscales, tarifas o penalizaciones por trabajar dentro del país, es probable que busquen aún más activamente alternativas viables. En primer lugar, existe un ecosistema emergente de talento creativo en países como México, Argentina, Colombia y, cada vez más, en la República Dominicana. En segundo lugar, los incentivos fiscales en países de la región se han vuelto más competitivos. Si Trump insiste en castigar a Hollywood, podría abrirle la puerta a un desplazamiento geocultural. El poder blando que tradicionalmente ha emanado de los estudios de Los Ángeles podría migrar hacia polos alternativos de producción cultural. El crecimiento repentino trae consigo desafíos: evitar convertirse en una simple fábrica de outsourcing, proteger y nutrir los propios cines nacionales y la cuestión de la identidad. En el caso dominicano, el impacto de un “Hollywood en crisis” puede ser doblemente significativo. República Dominicana podría convertirse en un nodo creativo de referencia en el Caribe. El intento de Donald Trump de penalizar a Hollywood puede tener consecuencias no deseadas. Para el cine latinoamericano, es una oportunidad histórica. Para la República Dominicana, un llamado a redoblar la apuesta por su talento, su voz y su capacidad de ser no solo locación, sino también inspiración.

title: How Mark Carney Emerged from the Oval Office Unscathed
content: In a day of congenial menace at the White House, Prime Minister Mark Carney picked his spots carefully. He got his key message across — but got a largely unrelated earful in exchange from U.S.
resumen:
During a White House meeting, Prime Minister Mark Carney pushed back against U.S. President Donald Trump's assertions that Canada should become the "51st state." Carney stated that Canada "will not be for sale, ever." Trump responded with "Never say never" and "Time will tell." Carney mouthed "Never" as the president spoke.

The meeting was dominated by Trump's commentary, including comments on Carney's recent election victory, American attacks on Yemen, and trade with China. Trump also mentioned his contempt for Carney’s predecessor, Justin Trudeau, and Canada’s former finance minister Chrystia Freeland.

Carney emphasized the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement (USCMA) as a basis for future talks, committed Canada to a "step change" in its military investment, and vowed to contribute to the president’s war on fentanyl trafficking. He also noted that Canada is America’s “biggest client.”

Trump suggested that USMCA may no longer be needed and even suggested it be terminated outright. Trump made false claims about the U.S. subsidizing Canada and implied the U.S. no longer wants fair trade with Canada.

Carney emphasized the need for a refurbished agreement between the two countries addressing trade irritants. Trump remained committed to reorganizing the American economy in a way that does not include Canada as an independent trading partner.

title: Lula, Petro y Boric viajan a China para estrechar lazos comerciales en plena guerra arancelaria
content: Los presidentes de Brasil, Colombia y Chile llegan a la nación asiática, donde el próximo 13 de mayo se celebra la cuarta reunión de ministros de Relaciones Exteriores del Foro China-Celac ...
resumen:
Los presidentes de Brasil, Colombia y Chile, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Gustavo Petro y Gabriel Boric, viajarán a China para estrechar lazos comerciales con el gigante asiático. La visita coincide con la cuarta reunión de ministros de Relaciones Exteriores del Foro China-Celac, que se celebra en Pekín el 13 de mayo.

En el caso de Brasil, China es su principal socio comercial y Lula se reunirá con Xi Jinping.

Gustavo Petro ha confirmado su interés en sumarse a la iniciativa de La Franja y la Ruta.

Gabriel Boric viajará para posicionar a “Chile como un actor relevante en la promoción del multilateralismo” frente al proteccionismo.

Fuentes del Gobierno mexicano confirmaron a EL PAÍS que la presidenta mexicana no viajará a la capital china.

Lula realizará un nuevo viaje a China, su primer socio comercial desde hace algo más de una década. Lula se reunirá con Xi Jinping. Ambos se encontraron hace seis meses, en Río de Janeiro, en la cumbre del G-20. Con este viaje de Estado a China, Lula pretende estrechar y diversificar la relación comercial con el gigante asiático, que está muy concentrada en el sector agropecuario. Lula y Xi tienen previsto suscribir una declaración conjunta en la que se prevé que defiendan el multilateralismo y la reforma de la ONU para ampliar el Consejo de Seguridad.

El viaje de Gustavo Petro se enmarca en la intención de sumarse a la iniciativa de La Franja y la Ruta. El mandatario ya visitó a Xi Jinping en octubre de 2023, pero entonces no llegó a concretar el acuerdo de intención que ahora sí se propone firmar.

El presidente de Chile, Gabriel Boric, ha intensificado el multilateralismo como un escudo ante el proteccionismo de Donald Trump. Esta será la segunda vez del mandatario en Pekín. La primera fue en 2023, y se espera que sostenga un encuentro con Xi Jinping. Boric viaja este viernes con una comitiva conformada por su canciller, Alberto van Klaveren, los ministros de Agricultura, Esteban Valenzuela; Transporte y Telecomunicaciones, Juan Carlos Muñoz; la ministra de las Culturas, Artes y Patrimonio, Carolina Arredondo; y la subsecretaria de Relaciones Económicas Internacionales, Claudia Sanhueza. También formarán parte de esta visita autoridades en materia de inversión, una delegación parlamentaria transversal, y empresarios. Los mayores intereses comerciales del país sudamericano están en Asia, donde se localiza su principal socio y comprador de cobre: China. El segundo mayor socio del país, Estados Unidos, le impuso gravámenes del 10%, solo excluyendo al cobre y la madera que se encuentran bajo evaluación.

title: “Canadá nunca estará en venta”: Carney, en encuentro con Trump, rechazó idea de que su país sea el estado 51 de EE. UU.
content: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país “nunca estará en venta”, durante una reunión en la ...
resumen:
El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país “nunca estará en venta”, durante una reunión en la Casa Blanca en medio de tensiones sobre aranceles y soberanía.
En su primer encuentro en la Oficina Oval, Trump insistió al recientemente elegido Carney que sería un “matrimonio maravilloso” si Canadá aceptara sus repetidos llamados para convertirse en el estado número 51 de Estados Unidos.
Carney afirmó haberle pedido a Trump en privado que dejara de insistir en que Canadá se anexe a Estados Unidos.
En la Oficina Oval, le había subrayado al magnate inmobiliario Trump que “hay lugares que nunca están en venta”.
Carney, líder del Partido Liberal, de 60 años, ganó las elecciones canadienses del 28 de abril con la promesa de plantar cara al republicano Trump, de 78 años.
Carney y Trump hablaron en un tono “positivo”.
Carney declaró en rueda de prensa que las negociaciones comerciales son “complejas”, pero que sus conversaciones de dos horas con Trump fueron “muy constructivas”.
Carney afirmó que le había pedido a Trump que dejara de instar a Canadá a ser su estado número 51.
Trump afirmó que no hubo tensión durante la reunión, que calificó de “magnífica”.
Trump impuso aranceles a Canadá y México, salvo para los productos incluidos en el Tratado de libre comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC).
Anteriormente, Carney fue gobernador del Banco de Canadá y del Banco de Inglaterra.

title: ‘Bai lan’ and how Trump’s tariffs are hurting China and helping the US
content: The objective of Trump's tariffs was to facilitate much-needed change and slowly but surely start to wean America's economy off its dependence on Beijing.
resumen: “Bai lan” is a Chinese colloquial expression that means “let it rot” or “let it decay.” In contemporary terms, it represents a phenomenon in China’s culture that describes an apathetic mindset and disposition to accept a deteriorating situation rather than engage in any effort to improve it. It’s analogous to the effects Trump’s tariffs can have on China. President Donald Trump started his political ambitions with a simple declaration: Make America great again. Over his presidential terms, this included confronting China on various economic issues, mainly concentrating on how the country has exploited the United States and our country’s (remaining) manufacturing capabilities and supply chain troubles for years. Trump’s tariffs on trade with China have caused geopolitical uncertainty worldwide. The objective of these tariffs was to facilitate much-needed change in the economic world order and slowly but surely start to wean America’s economy off its dependence on Beijing. This required strategic, long-term thinking that would benefit the country’s workforce and return manufacturing jobs to the country. This process began on “Liberation Day,” April 2, 2025. Trump’s tariff plans and disruption of the China supply chain racket unexpectedly threw a wrench into China’s plans. One of the fallouts of the COVID-19 pandemic was the startling realization that the U.S. was far too dependent on China. Trump is hellbent on trying to change this reality. Trump’s efforts are predicated on a course correction before the U.S. experiences “bai lan” or worse, suffers a fate similar to Rome in 410 A.D. and the Roman Empire in the fifth century. The little secret that liberals, Democrats, left-wingers, and their accomplices in the legacy media will not reveal is that Trump’s tariffs are hurting an already weakened Chinese economy. China is currently experiencing deflation. The unemployment rate is about 5%, with youth unemployment at a staggering 16.9% as of February 2025 (nearly twice the U.S. rate of 9.4%). Goldman Sachs cut China’s GDP forecast to 4% in 2025, and Citi analysts also cut China’s growth to about 4.2%. According to CNBC, the fallout in China from Trump’s tariffs “threatens to drive the world’s second-largest economy into deeper deflation.” Trump’s tariffs have hurt Chinese companies’ profitability due to the “recent influx of discounted goods” that were supposed to be shipped to the U.S. This could also significantly affect China’s unemployment rate in the future. The economic uncertainty over job prospects in the Chinese economy, related to the tariffs, has contributed to “weak consumer demand.” “After hovering just above zero in 2023 and 2024, the consumer price index slipped into negative territory, declining for two consecutive months in February and March,” noted CNBC. This is on top of the producer price index in China, which declined for the 29th consecutive month. The 2.5% drop experienced in March, compared to last year, was “its steepest decline in four months” — arguably a correlation to Trump’s tariffs. Adding to China’s woes are the possibility of Chinese stocks being delisted from American stock exchanges and recent trade negotiations between the U.S. and countries such as India and Italy.

resumen: Asian stocks rose at the open, and the dollar strengthened on confirmation that the US and China will hold dialogue, spurring optimism that trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies will ease. A gauge of regional equities gained, while index futures for the S&P 500 rose 0.8% on news that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with the Chinese government this week in Switzerland. The Australian dollar edged higher, while gold and Treasuries fell. The meeting will be first confirmed trade talks between the countries since President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs last month, led by punishing levies on China. Financial markets had gyrated on concerns that Trump ratcheting up his global trade war by imposing the highest levies in a century, and Beijing retaliating – will push the global economy into a recession. Trump placed duties as high as 145% on many Chinese imports, and Beijing retaliated with import taxes of 125% on American goods. The S&P 500 closed down 0.8% on Tuesday after Trump said he would prescribe tariff levels and concessions for partners looking to avoid higher duties. In Asia, China’s central bank and financial regulators will hold a press briefing at 9 am in Beijing to discuss policies aimed at stabilising markets. Investors are also focused on Wednesday’s rate decision by the Federal Reserve.

title: China Cuts Bank Reserve Ratio to Inject $138B Amid US Trade War
content: Chinas central bank has announced its first reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut of 2025 to bolster the economy amid intensifying trade tensions with the United States. Peoples Bank of China (PBOC) ...
resumen: China’s central bank announced its first reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut of 2025 to bolster the economy amid intensifying trade tensions with the United States. People's Bank of China (PBOC) Governor Pan Gongsheng said Wednesday the RRR will be lowered by 50 basis points, a move expected to inject approximately 1 trillion yuan ($138 billion) in liquidity into the financial system. The decision comes as China faces mounting economic pressure following U.S. President Donald Trump’s latest round of aggressive tariffs on Chinese goods. Beijing is stepping up monetary support to stabilize growth and ease credit conditions for businesses. The PBOC's action aligns with earlier commitments made at a key government meeting in late April, where Chinese officials pledged to adjust the RRR “in a timely manner” to counter external challenges and stimulate domestic demand. The liquidity boost is aimed at enhancing banks’ lending capacity, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, and maintaining overall financial stability. Policymakers have been cautious about aggressive stimulus, opting instead for targeted tools like RRR adjustments to fine-tune monetary conditions. This move also reflects broader efforts by Chinese authorities to manage the fallout from the ongoing U.S.-China trade war. The PBOC’s latest intervention underscores China’s commitment to sustaining growth amid external shocks, with liquidity support emerging as a key lever in its economic strategy.

title: Effects of Trump’s trade war loom over the Port of Virginia
content: Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United State economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.
resumen:
The Port of Virginia supports 1.29 million jobs, employs 565,000 people in Virginia and accounts for over $100 billion added to the national economy, 2021 data says.

Local experts and officials don’t have a clear picture of how the Trump administration’s tariff policy will affect the Port of Virginia and the many thousands of jobs connected to it, but ports across the country are bracing for a significant slowdown in traffic.

Impacts will be felt between May and July, according to Vinod Agarwal, a professor of economics at Old Dominion University and deputy director for ODU’s Dragas Center for Economic Analysis and Policy.

The tariffs are levied on “just about every trade lane we have,” said Joe Harris, a spokesperson for the Port of Virginia.

Port of Virginia CEO Stephen Edwards said, “very plainly, it’s hard to know.”

The port had its second-busiest March on record, according to Harris.

Agarwal said is “simply because everyone knew the tariffs would be taking place in April and if you’re in the business of importing goods you want to make sure they arrive in time before the tariffs go into effect.”

Tariffs should lead to a decrease in imports at almost all U.S. ports, not just the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

The effect of the tariffs has not yet been seen in as much detail as is likely to be seen in the next couple of months.

The tariffs will lead to increases in prices, the higher prices will result in decreased demand for these products, so we should see a decline in imports which will of course affect the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United States economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.

Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, which had an economic impact of $311 billion in 2021, said they’ve seen roughly 33% drop off in their import volume over the last few weeks.

Apollo Global Management estimates U.S. consumers could start seeing shortages on store shelves by mid- to late-May, that there will be layoffs in the trucking and retail industries in late May and early June, and that there will be a recession by this summer.

resumen: Mattel CEO Ynon Kreiz cast doubt on the notion that Mattel might move its manufacturing to the United States in light of President Trump’s tariffs on Chinese goods in an appearance on CNBC’s “Squawk Box” on Tuesday. Mattel does see rising prices in the US. Kreiz cited three key strategies the company is deploying to mitigate the costs of Trump’s trade war, with “pricing action,” among them. Mattel withdrew its annual financial forecast, explaining in its first quarter earnings report that, “Given the volatile macroeconomic environment and evolving U.S. tariff landscape, it is difficult to predict consumer spending and Mattel’s U.S. sales in the remainder of the year and holiday season.” Mattel also said it had raised its cost savings target for the year from $60 million to $80 million, part of which would be achieved by cutting promotions and discounts. The company also laid off more than one hundred employees from its Headquarters in El Segundo, CA, at the end of March. Kreiz said that the company is also focused on diversifying its global supply chain to reduce its reliance on China. In two years, no single country will represent more than 25% of Mattel’s sourcing. Mattel also imports products (which include Barbies, Hot Wheels, and American Girl Dolls) from Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Those countries were also the targets of reciprocal tariffs announced by the Trump administration in early April before being paused for 90 days. President Trump addressed the impact tariffs would have on the toy industry (80% of global toy production takes place in China), saying in a cabinet meeting that, “Well, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls, you know? And maybe the two dolls will cost a couple of bucks more than they would normally.” Kreiz emphasized that Mattel is committed to producing a steady supply of product at a “wide range of affordable price points.” Roth analyst Eric Handler told CNBC that Mattel expects to keep between 40% and 50% of its products under $20. The Toy Association, a trade group representing the US toy industry, has pushed hard for an exemption from Trump’s tariffs since they were announced. Kreiz expressed his support for the group’s advocacy in the interview, saying that toys are “an essential part of children’s lives.” Kreiz came to Mattel in 2018 from Maker Studios. The Barbie brand posted its best full-year sales results of all time in 2021 under Krez’s leadership. Last week, speaking to reporters during a cabinet meeting, President Trump said that “maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls,” this Christmas season.
