title: Bessent Pitches Skittish Investors to Bet on Trump’s Economic Plan
content: The Treasury secretary urged executives and entrepreneurs to look beyond the Trump administration’s trade agenda.
resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, instó a los líderes empresariales mundiales a ignorar a los detractores económicos del presidente Trump y a aumentar la inversión en Estados Unidos, defendiendo una agenda económica que, según los economistas, frenará el crecimiento económico y exacerbará la inflación.

El Sr. Bessent argumentó que los planes económicos de la administración Trump van más allá de la política comercial y darán sus frutos a largo plazo. Instó a los líderes a centrarse también en los planes del Sr. Trump de recortar impuestos y regulaciones, lo que, según dijo, impulsaría la creación de empleo y la producción.

El Sr. Bessent dijo en el Milken Institute Global Conference en Los Ángeles: "Los aranceles están diseñados para animar a empresas como la suya a invertir directamente en Estados Unidos. Se alegrarán de haberlo hecho, no solo porque tenemos la fuerza laboral más productiva del mundo, sino también porque pronto tendremos el entorno fiscal y regulatorio más favorable".

Sus comentarios se produjeron pocas horas después de que el Sr. Trump ordenara nuevos aranceles a los productores de cine extranjeros.

El secretario del Tesoro ha estado trabajando para aliviar las preocupaciones entre los inversores de que los planes comerciales del Sr. Trump desestabilizarán la economía global. El mes pasado, el presidente impuso aranceles a países de todo el mundo y escaló una disputa comercial con China, lo que hizo que los mercados financieros se desplomaran.

Desde entonces, el Sr. Bessent ha estado negociando acuerdos comerciales con docenas de países. También ha señalado que los aranceles chinos no son sostenibles, ofreciendo la esperanza de que el Sr. Trump pronto comenzaría las negociaciones para reducirlos.

El Sr. Bessent dijo: "Nuestro objetivo con la política comercial es nivelar el campo de juego para nuestros grandes trabajadores y empresas estadounidenses".

Los líderes empresariales siguen nerviosos por el enfoque desordenado de la administración Trump para establecer la política comercial.

El Sr. Trump publicó en Truth Social que estaba ordenando a sus agencias gubernamentales "comenzar inmediatamente el proceso de instituir un arancel del 100% sobre todas y cada una de las películas que ingresen a nuestro país y que se produzcan en tierras extranjeras". Sin embargo, un portavoz de la Casa Blanca dijo que "no se han tomado decisiones finales sobre los aranceles cinematográficos extranjeros" y que la administración aún estaba considerando sus opciones.

A pesar de los llamamientos del Sr. Bessent a los inversores para que adopten una visión a largo plazo de la economía estadounidense, los ejecutivos en la reunión del Instituto Milken dejaron claro que los aranceles estaban pasando factura.

Jan Fraser, directora ejecutiva de Citigroup, dijo: "Lo que estamos escuchando de los clientes es que se están preparando para vientos en contra", y señaló que algunas empresas estaban adelantando el gasto, algunas estaban retrasando la inversión y todas estaban siendo más cautelosas mientras esperaban a ver cómo la administración Trump procedía con sus planes arancelarios.

Harvey Schwartz, director ejecutivo de Carlyle Group, dijo que una guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China era problemática para la economía mundial y que los aranceles han socavado parte del entusiasmo por la agenda económica del Sr. Trump que prevalecía cuando asumió el cargo en enero.

El Sr. Schwartz dijo: "Creo que entramos en el año y había una expectativa y un impulso extraordinariamente altos y todo era pro-crecimiento. Y creo que con la política arancelaria, la gente se quedó un poco confundida e incierta, porque se sintió como un cambio tan drástico en la política. Esta es una iniciativa política que nunca hemos visto".

El Sr. Bessent ha intentado cambiar la discusión política a los recortes de impuestos, que predijo que el Congreso podría aprobar a principios de julio.

La administración Trump está trabajando en estrecha colaboración con los republicanos del Congreso en una legislación fiscal que extendería los recortes de impuestos de 2017 y ofrecería nuevas exenciones fiscales para las horas extras, las propinas y los beneficios de la Seguridad Social. El Sr. Bessent dijo que el proyecto de ley incluiría créditos y deducciones fiscales para la investigación y la innovación para estimular la inversión en operaciones de alta tecnología e incentivos fiscales para la compra de equipos y la construcción de fábricas.

El Sr. Bessent argumentó que los inversores deben considerar la agenda más amplia al pensar dónde estacionar su dinero.

Describiendo las políticas del Sr. Trump como "mutuamente reforzantes", el Sr. Bessent dijo: "Actuando en concierto, empujan hacia el mismo objetivo: consolidar nuestra posición como el hogar del capital global".

Los inversores se han vuelto cada vez más cautelosos con las políticas del Sr. Trump en los últimos meses, con acciones, bonos y el dólar mostrando signos de debilidad a medida que los administradores de fondos se preocupan por la incertidumbre que rodea el enfoque de formulación de políticas del Sr. Trump.

El Fondo Monetario Internacional proyectó el mes pasado que la producción mundial se desaceleraría al 2,8 por ciento este año desde el 3,3 por ciento en 2024 y rebajó drásticamente sus perspectivas para la economía estadounidense.

Kristalina Georgieva, directora gerente del F.M.I., dijo en la conferencia de Milken: "Claramente, estamos experimentando una turbulencia significativa en el comercio mundial. Ahora estamos pasando de un régimen comercial predecible que teníamos antes a lo que eventualmente será un nuevo equilibrio. Lo que el mundo está pagando por ese cambio, de un equilibrio a algo nuevo, no es trivial".

A pesar de esas preocupaciones, el Sr. Bessent dijo que el Sr. Trump demostraría que "los críticos en los círculos del establishment" estaban equivocados.

El Sr. Bessent dijo: "Tenemos la moneda de reserva del mundo, los mercados más profundos y líquidos y los derechos de propiedad más fuertes. Por estas razones, Estados Unidos es el principal destino del capital internacional".

Alan Rappeport es reportero de política económica de The Times, con sede en Washington. Cubre el Departamento del Tesoro y escribe sobre impuestos, comercio y asuntos fiscales.

title: Trump hints at China tariff cut: will Bitcoin price soar past $100K as trade tensions ease?
content: The announcement comes amid escalating speculation about how such a policy shift could impact inflation, interest rates, and digital assets like Bitcoin and Ethereum.
resumen: Trump acknowledged that the existing 145% US tariff on Chinese imports is “too high”. The US and China are locked in a steep tariff battle. Bitcoin and Ethereum have shown strong performance during periods of dovish monetary policy and reduced inflation. US President Donald Trump has signaled a willingness to lower tariffs on Chinese goods. Trump’s comments have already sparked renewed interest among crypto investors. Speaking in a recent CNBC interview, President Trump acknowledged that the existing 145% US tariff on Chinese imports is “too high” and has effectively crippled bilateral trade. “At some point, I’m going to lower them,” he said, adding that China is eager to resume business with the United States. The US and China are locked in a steep tariff battle, with Beijing retaliating by imposing a 125% duty on American goods. Industry analysts believe that easing these levies could reduce inflationary pressure, thereby influencing the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy, particularly in holding back further interest rate hikes. Digital assets such as Bitcoin and Ethereum have shown strong performance during periods of dovish monetary policy and reduced inflation. Bitcoin recently dipped below $80,000 but has since bounced back, trading above $94,000 at press time. Analysts predict that if sentiment continues to improve, Bitcoin could breach the $100,000 milestone. Beyond Bitcoin, altcoins like Ethereum (ETH), Ripple (XRP), and Solana (SOL) also stand to gain from a more favorable economic environment.

title: Ford Says Tariffs Will Cost Company $1.5 Billion in 2025
content: Ford is less affected by President Trump’s 25 percent tariffs on vehicles than other automakers because most of the vehicles it sells in the United States are made in the country. General Motors said ...
resumen:
Ford Motor dijo el lunes que las políticas arancelarias de la administración Trump probablemente reducirían sus ganancias de 2025, antes de intereses e impuestos, en aproximadamente $1.5 mil millones. La compañía también abandonó su pronóstico para el año, diciendo que predecir el futuro se había vuelto demasiado difícil.

Ford se ve menos afectado por los aranceles del 25 por ciento del presidente Trump sobre los vehículos que otros fabricantes de automóviles porque la mayoría de los vehículos que vende en los Estados Unidos se fabrican en el país. General Motors dijo la semana pasada que los aranceles aumentarían sus costos entre $4 mil millones y $5 mil millones este año.

"Creemos que estamos bien posicionados para adaptarnos a los cambios que los aranceles están impulsando en nuestra industria", dijo la directora financiera de Ford, Sherry House, en una conferencia telefónica.

La compañía dijo que las cambiantes políticas arancelarias de la administración tenían el potencial de interrumpir las cadenas de suministro automotrices, y podrían obligar a otras naciones a imponer aranceles de represalia a las exportaciones estadounidenses. También señaló una mayor incertidumbre en las políticas fiscales y de emisiones de la administración Trump.

"Consideramos prudente suspender nuestra guía para todo el año", dijo la Sra. House.

Ford dijo anteriormente que esperaba ganancias para 2025, antes de intereses e impuestos, de $7 mil millones a $8.5 mil millones.

La administración Trump ha impuesto aranceles del 25 por ciento a los vehículos y autopartes importados. Ha aumentado los aranceles sobre el acero y el aluminio importados, que se utilizan ampliamente en automóviles y camiones.

Esos y otros aranceles impuestos por el Sr. Trump significan un cambio importante en la política comercial de Estados Unidos, especialmente en lo que respecta al comercio entre Estados Unidos, Canadá y México. Durante décadas, los automóviles y las autopartes se han enviado por toda América del Norte con pocos o ningún arancel.

Ford fabrica algunos vehículos en México, incluido un modelo eléctrico clave, el Mustang Mach-E, y planea comenzar a fabricar camionetas de servicio pesado en Canadá en 2026. La Sra. House dijo que el fabricante de automóviles no estaba considerando cambiar sus planes de camiones de servicio pesado.

La compañía también informó que sus ganancias en los primeros tres meses del año cayeron a $471 millones, de $1.3 mil millones un año antes. Ford culpó a la disminución de las ventas de vehículos porque había pausado la producción en algunas fábricas para prepararse para nuevos modelos e hizo otros cambios destinados a reducir los inventarios de automóviles y camiones sin vender.

Sus ingresos en el trimestre disminuyeron un 5 por ciento, a $40.7 mil millones. Ford redujo su pérdida en vehículos eléctricos a $849 millones de una pérdida de $1.3 mil millones un año antes. Las ganancias de la venta de vehículos convencionales de combustión interna cayeron a $96 millones de $901 millones. Las ganancias de la venta de camiones comerciales y servicios relacionados disminuyeron a $1.3 mil millones de $3 mil millones.

title: Ford says Trump’s tariffs will cost the company $1.5bn in 2025
content: Ford had previously said it expected earnings for 2025, before interest and taxes, to be $7 billion to $8.5 billion.
resumen: Ford Motor Company said on Monday that the Trump administration’s tariff policies were likely to lower its 2025 profit, before interest and taxes, by about $1.5 billion (€1.3 billion). The company also dropped its forecast for the year. Ford is less affected by US president Donald Trump’s 25 per cent tariffs on vehicles than other automakers. Ford had previously said it expected earnings for 2025, before interest and taxes, to be $7 billion to $8.5 billion. The Trump administration has levied 25 per cent tariffs on imported vehicles and auto parts. Ford makes some vehicles — including a key electric model, the Mustang Mach-E — in Mexico, and the company plans to start making heavy-duty pickup trucks in Canada in 2026. The company also reported that its profit in the first three months of the year fell to $471 million from $1.3 billion in the same period a year ago. Its revenue in the quarter declined 5 per cent, to $40.7 billion. Ford narrowed its loss on electric vehicles to $849 million from a loss of $1.3 billion a year ago. Profit from selling mainstream, internal combustion vehicles fell to $96 million from $901 million. Profit from selling commercial trucks and related services declined to $1.3 billion from $3 billion last year.

title: ‘Tariff challenge could make Asian economies resilient’
content: The uncertainty created by the Trump administration on global trade and economic growth could still create opportunities for Asian economies if they remain on the reform path and dispel any sense of ...
resumen: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Masato Kanda stated that the uncertainty created by the Trump administration on global trade and economic growth could still create opportunities for Asian economies if they remain on the reform path and dispel any sense of complacency from their economic successes. Higher US tariffs imposed on Asian goods have created much uncertainty. The region is more resilient now than before, owing to not only the benefits of open trade but also greater interconnectedness. Kanda believes this is a good opportunity for Asian and Pacific countries to turn these challenges into the opportunity to make their economies more resilient, stronger, and open, and interconnected in the region and with their new partners, and that they probably need to continue the reform path. ADB can help the region by drawing from its “massive firepower” to fight off the uncertainties that Trump’s tariff war brings, including countercyclical financial assistance or the debt management support in the region, and a trade supply chain enhancement program. The key to creating opportunities amid uncertainties include boosting domestic demand, diversifying industries and trade partners as well as supply chain destinations. ADB has 1,000 additional people utilizing this firepower and together with the partnership with the countries they will help them reform to the more diverse economy and they are deepening their capital and financial markets. Kanda reiterated his points on the uncertainties facing Asia and the Pacific and how this can be an opportunity for a resilient and sustainable future at the ADB’s 58th Annual Meeting of the Board of Governors. External shocks, debt burdens, and climate change weigh heavily on the people and economies of the region. Growth remains solid, trade and economic integration are deepening, supply chains are diversifying, and digital connectivity and innovation are accelerating. Italian Minister of Economy and Finance Giancarlo Giorgetti and Governor of the Bank of Italy and Chair of the ADB Board of Governors Fabio Panetta also spoke at the Opening Session, emphasizing Italy’s partnership with ADB. ADB has been working to solve complex challenges together with its members and partners, both regional and nonregional. ADB is increasing its financing for food and nutrition security in Asia and the Pacific to $40 billion by 2030 as more people struggle with surging food prices and the threats of climate change. This is a $26-billion increase from the $14 billion average between 2022 and 2025. The spike in food prices has been forcing families to choose between spending for meals and non-food items like transportation. The increase in financing from ADB will help feed 270 million people in the region and increase food production and agriculture-linked jobs.

title: 100 days in: Here's where President Trump's policies have mirrored Project 2025
content: He distanced himself on the campaign trail, but here's where Trump's policies align with the conservative playbook.
resumen:
Despite distancing himself from Project 2025 on the campaign trail, there have been substantial parallels between the initiative and President Donald Trump’s second administration.

There was a lot of conversation surrounding Project 2025 in the months leading up to the November election, largely due to its calls to significantly reduce and reshape the scope of the federal government.

At the September debate against former Vice President Kamala Harris, Trump said he had “nothing to do with Project 2025.” On his Truth Social platform, Trump also repeatedly posted about having nothing to do with Project 2025, and in a July post he called parts of it “ridiculous and abysmal.”

Now, 100 days into his second administration, nearly 45% of Trump's executive orders closely mirror policy recommendations Project 2025 advocates for, according to an analysis by the Hearst Television Data Team.

Project 2025 is an initiative spearheaded by conservative think tank The Heritage Foundation that gives guidance for what policies the next conservative president should carry out. The initiative began in 2022, and its main policy guidebook — the 922-page “Mandate for Leadership: The Conservative Promise” — was published a year later.

In order to determine if there were overlaps between Trump administration policies and Project 2025, the Hearst Television Data Team analyzed how many executive orders align with policy recommendations in the “Mandate for Leadership.” Any executive order involving tariffs was excluded from the analysis due to Project 2025’s conflicting recommendations on the issue.

Of the 126 non-tariff executive orders, 56 contain policy recommendations that closely mirror Project 2025.

One of the largest areas where there is overlap between Project 2025 and Trump’s executive orders is on the issue of government reform, accountability and deregulation. While Project 2025 does not explicitly call for the creation of the Department of Government Efficiency, it does advocate for many of the government workforce and reduction changes that Trump’s executive orders carry out.

In his first 100 days, Trump has brought back Schedule F, making it easier to fire federal employees, eliminated DEI from the federal government, reinstated service members with backpay who were discharged under former President Joe Biden’s COVID-19 vaccine mandate, and called for agencies to cut back on costs. All of these actions were advocated for in Project 2025.

On March 30, Trump issued an Executive Order to begin the dismantling of the Department of Education — one of the policies in Project 2025 that made a lot of headlines before the election.

Trump and Project 2025 have also aligned on various policies to boost domestic energy production, strengthen immigration enforcement, and implement deregulations.

The two do differ on a couple of key issues. Project 2025 calls for an outright ban on TikTok, citing national security risks. Trump has yet to make a final call on TikTok, but has delayed its banning in the U.S.

Project 2025 also gives conflicting advice regarding tariffs. Author Kent Lassman laid out an argument for free trade that critiqued tariffs. Author Peter Navarro — who ultimately Trump hired as his senior counselor for trade and manufacturing — argued for tariffs to strengthen domestic manufacturing.

While ideas are shared between Project 2025 and the executive orders Trump has signed, it is unclear the extent to which one influenced the other. Project 2025 was created by a think tank whose aim is to influence political policy. It is just one of many similar proposals created by conservative policy groups — unique largely in how it captured the media’s attention last summer and Trump’s claim he had “nothing to do with it.”

Many authors of Project 2025 are now members of Trump’s top team of officials. Budget Director Russ Vought, FCC Chair Brendan Carr and Navarro were all authors of Project 2025. Additionally, CIA Director John Ratcliffe, Border Czar Tom Homan, and Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Paul Atkins were all among the contributors to Project 2025.

title: Rupiah Strengthens as US-China Trade Tension Eases
content: The Indonesian rupiah has started to regain ground amid signs of easing trade tensions between the United States and China, analysts said on Friday.
resumen:
The Indonesian rupiah has started to regain ground amid signs of easing trade tensions between the United States and China, analysts said Friday, May 2.

Rully Nova, an economist at Bank Woori, attributed the rupiah's strengthening to improved global sentiment following a thaw in tariff disputes between the world's two largest economies.

Rully said the rupiah is expected to close stronger today, in the Rp16,550–Rp16,450 range, driven by cooling global tensions — particularly China's softer stance and willingness to reopen trade talks with the U.S., as quoted by state news agency Antara.

According to Rully, China's readiness to return to the negotiating table stems from its ongoing reliance on U.S. industrial raw materials. He also noted that China's economic recovery remains heavily dependent on exports, as its domestic property sector has yet to bounce back from previous downturns.

Rully said there are no winners in a tariff war — both the U.S. and China end up losing.

Looking ahead, Rully expects the two countries to forge a mutually beneficial relationship in trade and investment, which could help stabilize market sentiment further.

On the domestic front, Indonesia's Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported a monthly inflation rate of 1.17 percent in April 2025 — a sign that the recent deflationary trend may have run its course, as the broader economy shows signs of entering an expansionary phase.

Rully added that this gives Bank Indonesia some room to cut its benchmark interest rate.

Lukman Leong, a currency and commodity strategist at Doo Financial Futures, warned that the rupiah could weaken following remarks by U.S. President Donald Trump, who suggested that tariff agreements with multiple trading partners were in the works.

Leong said the rupiah may depreciate as the US dollar strengthens broadly in response to Trump's comments on potential deals with India, South Korea, Japan, and China.

Adam Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics (PIIE), recently placed the odds of a U.S. recession at 65 percent, citing policy uncertainty as a key risk.

Gary Clyde Hufbauer, a non-resident senior fellow at PIIE, echoed that view, predicting a likely recession in the second half of 2025. He pointed to weakening consumer sentiment and growing business uncertainty, which are expected to weigh on second-quarter GDP growth.

The Kobeissi Letter, a financial publication, reported that the US economy contracted by 0.3 percent in the first quarter of 2025 — well below market expectations of 0.3 percent growth. This marked the first and steepest contraction since the second quarter of 2022 and has heightened concerns that a recession is now the base-case scenario for the rest of the year.

Leong noted that investor focus has shifted toward tariff developments.

Back in Jakarta, the rupiah briefly weakened at the start of Friday's trading session, slipping 25 points or 0.15 percent to Rp16,602 per US dollar from Rp16,577. But by the close of the day, the currency had rallied, gaining 139 points or around 0.84 percent to end at Rp16,438 per dollar.

title: Canadá advierte sobre daños en ese país y Estados Unidos si aplican aranceles al sector audiovisual
content: La industria audiovisual y las autoridades canadienses criticaron este lunes la intención del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a las producciones realizadas en el extra ...
resumen:
La industria audiovisual y las autoridades canadienses criticaron la intención del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a las producciones realizadas en el extranjero y advirtieron que causarían graves daños en Canadá y Estados Unidos.

El presidente de la Asociación de Productores de Canadá (APC), Reynolds Mastin, señaló que la propuesta “causará una significante disrupción y dificultades económicas en los sectores de producción a ambos lados de la frontera entre Canadá y Estados Unidos”.

Según Mastin, las palabras de Trump “subrayan la enorme importancia de garantizar que Canadá cuente con una industria mediática nacional fuerte e independiente”.

Muchas películas de Hollywood además de series de televisión y producciones de plataformas de retransmisión por internet son filmados en Canadá gracias a las ventajas económicas que el país ofrece a los estudios.

La provincia de Columbia Británica es el tercer lugar de Norteamérica donde más producciones se filman, solo por detrás de California y Nueva York.

La provincia de Ontario, donde se sitúa Toronto, es el cuarto destino.

En Toronto se han rodado películas de Hollywood como ‘La forma del agua’ (2017), ‘Suicide Squad’ (2016), ‘Brokeback Mountain’ (2005) o ‘Chicago’ (2002), además de series como ‘Suits’ (2011-2019).

En Vancouver se han producido filmes como ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ (2015), ‘Deadpool’ (2016) o ‘Jumanji’ (1995).

El sindicato de actores de Canadá (ACTRA) señaló que en 2023-2024 el sector audiovisual contribuyó con 11,000 millones de dólares canadienses (8,000 millones de dólares estadounidenses o 7,000 millones de euros) al Producto Interior Bruto (PIB) de Canadá.

En Toronto, las producciones generaron 2,600 millones de dólares canadienses en 2022.

La alcaldesa de Toronto, Olivia Chow, declaró que el sector emplea a 30.000 personas en la ciudad y afirmó que los aranceles sería “devastadores”.

El ministro de Desarrollo Económico de Ontario, Vic Fedeli, afirmó que los aranceles propuestos por Trump son un “asalto directo” a la provincia.

title: FACTBOX-Trump’s tariffs and threatened trade actions
content: ALCOHOL: Trump on March 13 threatened to slap a 200% tariff on wine, cognac and other alcohol imports from Europe, in response to a European Union plan to impose tariffs on American whiskey and other ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump said on Sunday that his top priority was to secure a fair trade deal with China.

Signs of a de-escalation in the trade war with China appeared after U.S. officials engaged in a flurry of meetings with trading partners after April 2, when Trump imposed a 10% tariff on most countries and suspended higher levies on many trading partners for 90 days.

The duties are now scheduled to kick in on July 8.

He has also imposed 25% tariffs on autos, steel and aluminium, 25% levies on imports from Canada and Mexico and 145% tariffs on China.

In his latest move, Trump imposed a 100% tariff on movies produced outside the United States and sent into the country.

A cornerstone of Trump’s vision includes a phased rollout of universal tariffs on all U.S. imports.

Trump had tasked his economics team with devising plans for reciprocal tariffs on every country that taxes U.S. imports and to counteract non-tariff barriers such as vehicle safety rules that exclude U.S. autos, as well as value-added taxes that increase their cost.

MEXICO AND CANADA: The two countries were the largest trading partners of the U.S. in 2024 through November, with Mexico ranked first. Trump’s new 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada took effect on March 4 as a retaliation for migration and fentanyl trafficking.

The tariffs included a 25% levy on most goods from Mexico and Canada, along with a 10% duty on Canada’s energy imports.

Canada primarily exports crude oil and other energy goods, as well as cars and auto parts within the North American auto manufacturing chain.

Mexico also exports various goods to the U.S. in the industrial and auto sectors.

Canada hit back with 25% tariffs on C$30 billion ($21.13 billion) worth of U.S. imports, including orange juice, peanut butter, beer, coffee, appliances and motorcycles.

The Canadian government added that it would impose additional tariffs on C$125 billion of U.S. goods if Trump’s tariffs were still in place in 21 days, with the potential inclusion of vehicles, steel, aircraft, beef and pork.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said U.S. officials might still work out a partial resolution with the two neighbours, adding that they needed to do more on the fentanyl front.

On March 12, Canada said it would impose retaliatory tariffs on U.S. imported goods worth C$29.8 billion ($20 billion) in response to Trump’s steel and aluminium tariffs.

While the two countries are currently exempt from the”Liberation Day” tariffs announced on April 2, they do face a separate set of 25% tariffs on auto imports.

Canada has requested WTO dispute consultations with the U.S. over its imposition of import duties on certain steel and aluminium products, as well as the levies on cars and car parts from Canada.

CHINA: Trump levied 10% tariffs across all Chinese imports into the U.S., effective on February 4, following repeated warnings to Beijing about insufficient measures to halt the flow of illicit drugs into the U.S.

He followed that up with another 10% duty on Chinese goods, effective March 4.

China responded by announcing additional tariffs of 10% to 15% on certain U.S. imports from March 10 and a series of new export restrictions for designated U.S. entities.

Later, it raised complaints about the U.S. tariffs with the WTO.

On April 2, Trump imposed an additional 34% tariff on China, bringing the total new levy to 54%, which prompted the world’s second-biggest economy to retaliate with a duty of 34% on all U.S. goods.

Trump responded that the U.S. would impose an additional 50% tariff on China if Beijing does not withdraw its retaliatory tariffs on the U.S., and said “all talks with China concerning their requested meetings with us will be terminated.”

Washington’s fresh round of tariffs lifted duties on China to an eye-watering 145%, prompting Beijing to jack up levies on U.S. goods by 125% in an intensifying trade war between the world’s two biggest economies.

EUROPE: Trump said the EU and other countries have troubling trade surpluses with the U.S.

He has said the countries’ products will either be subject to tariffs or he will demand they buy more oil and gas from the U.S., even though U.S. gas export capacity is near its limits.

The 27-nation bloc faces 25% import tariffs on steel, aluminium, and cars, as well as broader tariffs of 20% from April 9 for almost all other goods.

Among vulnerable industries is pharmaceuticals, as U.S. firms such as Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer have large plants in Ireland, which is also a major exporter of medical devices.

The European Union said on April 7 it had offered a”zero-for-zero” tariff deal to avert a trade war, with EU ministers agreeing to prioritise negotiations while striking back with targeted countermeasures next week.

The EU on March 12 said it would impose counter-tariffs on 26 billion euros ($28 billion) worth of U.S. goods from next month in response to Trump’s metals tariffs.

The bloc is expected to produce a larger package of countermeasures by the end of April as a response to U.S. car and broader tariffs.

On March 13, Trump threatened to slap a 200% tariff on European wine and spirits in response to the EU plan to impose tariffs on American whiskey and other products next month.

AUTOS: On March 26, Trump unveiled a 25% tariff on imported cars and light trucks.

The 25% levy would be imposed on top of previous duties on imports of finished vehicles starting on April 3.

However, on April 29, he signed a pair of orders to soften the blow of his auto tariffs with a mix of credits and relief from other levies on materials.

In a partial rollback of his tariff policies, the Republican president has granted automakers a two-year window to increase the share of domestic components in vehicles built in the U.S.

METALS: On March 12, Trump increased tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports to 25%, and extended the duties to hundreds of downstream products, from nuts and bolts to bulldozer blades and soda cans.

The U.S. is the world’s largest aluminum importer and the second-largest steel importer, with more than half of those volumes coming from Canada, Mexico and Brazil.

Trump on February 25 ordered a fresh probe into possible new tariffs on copper imports to rebuild U.S. production of the metal critical in electric vehicles, military hardware, semiconductors and a wide range of consumer goods.

title: A Message from the Market
content: When US president Donald Trump detonated a trade bomb on 2nd April, with levies set to bite from 9th April, global markets shuddered. Stocks tumbled for four days as investors braced for chaos. Yet, ...
resumen: When US president Donald Trump detonated a trade bomb on 2nd April, with levies set to bite from 9th April, global markets shuddered. Stocks tumbled for four days as investors braced for chaos. Yet, days later, president Trump paused the tariffs for 90 days on all—excluding China—and exempted electronics, triggering a relief rally. The German market has hit a lifetime high. The S&P500 has recorded nine consecutive days of positive closing, its longest winning streak in 20 years, and on Friday, it closed at 5,686—above its pre-tariff level. The Indian market climbed 3.5% in April. Yale University’s Budget Lab estimates the 2025 tariffs will lift US consumer prices by 2.3%, costing households US$3,800 annually (in 2024 dollars). Car prices could rise by US$2,000–US$10,000, iPhones by 40%, and groceries will not be spared. The IMF, citing the tariffs, slashed its 2025 US growth forecast from 2.7% to 1.8% and pegged the global recession risk at 60%, up from 40%. US GDP growth may shrink by 0.9 percentage points in 2025. The US Consumers’ Expectations Index dropped 12.5 points to 54.4, the lowest level since October 2011. The obvious initial driver of market gains has been president Trump’s 90-day pause on ‘reciprocal’ tariffs for most countries, excluding China. This sparked a massive market rally, with the S&P 500 soaring 9.5%—its third-best day since 1940—and the Nasdaq jumping 12.2%. Investors now appear to be wagering that this trade war, too, will end in an eleventh-hour compromise. While institutions have sold off through April, retail investors have been buying the dip. April saw 177,000 new jobs, and inflation cooled to 2.4% in March, below forecasts of 2.6%. In India, a weakening dollar against the rupee lured foreign investors back, while domestic funds, now outstripping their foreign counterparts in holdings, kept buying. Over 200 lawsuits have been filed challenging a range of executive actions, with 70 federal rulings—on issues from immigration to federal spending—thwarting his plans. The Supreme Court has already blocked deportations under the Alien Enemies Act, and Mr Trump’s use of the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose tariffs may yet be struck down as illegal.

title: Bajan del 75 % al 63 % las empresas españolas que aumentarán inversiones en Latinoamérica
content: Madrid, 6 may (EFE).- Un 63 % de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, con un descenso "significativo" en comparación con los últimos años, cuando la cifra solía ron ...
resumen:
Un 63 % de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, con un descenso "significativo" en comparación con los últimos años, cuando la cifra solía rondar el 75 %, según el informe anual 'Panorama de Inversión Española en Iberoamérica 2025', de IE University.
Otro 30 %. de las empresas española prevé mantener sus inversiones en Latinoamérica y el 7 % las disminuirán.
En el caso de las empresas pequeñas y medianas (pymes), solo la mitad considera aumentar su apuesta por la región, un descenso "brusco" respecto al 80 % de años anteriores.
México será el país más "afectado económicamente" por su alta exposición a Estados Unidos, pero volverá a ser donde más empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones, seguido por Colombia, y Chile, Perú y Brasil. También subirán en Costa Rica y Paraguay, y se mantendrán en el resto en general.
Respecto a Argentina, y a pesar de sus "enormes dificultades", las empresas españolas creen que será el país con un mejor desempeño económico en 2025 en la zona, seguida por Uruguay y República Dominicana. Cierran Venezuela, Cuba y Nicaragua.
Por primera vez, no será Iberoamérica (64 %), sino la Unión Europea (71 %) el mercado en el que más empresas españolas prevén subir sus ventas en ese plazo.
La volatilidad cambiaria es, este año, "el aspecto que más afectará a las ventas y negocios de las empresas españolas, por encima de la inestabilidad jurídica y de la inflación, según la encuesta.
El atractivo de los mercados internos vuelve a ser la mayor ventaja que encuentra para invertir (67 %), seguida por la mano de obra cualificada.
Entre las amenazas percibidas, destacan la inestabilidad política (76 %) y el ya mencionado riesgo cambiario (56 %).

title: Where is the Trade War Heading?
content: A trade deal between China and the United States is nowhere in sight. The mountain of issues could take a long time and enormous effort to resolve. It’s certainly not going to happen in three or four ...
resumen:
A trade deal between China and the United States is nowhere in sight. The mountain of issues could take a long time and enormous effort to resolve. It’s certainly not going to happen in three or four weeks, as Trump has suggested. More likely, it will be months, if not years.

With China and the United States deadlocked in a trade war initiated by U.S. President Donald Trump, two important questions are being raised: When can the two countries be expected to enter into negotiations? And how quickly can a deal be struck?

So far this year, Trump has imposed tariffs totaling 145 percent on goods from China. The levies are hurting. The country’s manufacturing activity is shrinking as orders of goods bound for America are canceled and factory workers are laid off.

However, Beijing says it will not bend under economic pressure. China is determined to avoid the fate that Japan suffered in the wake of the Plaza Accord and to maintain its rightful place in the world. For years, it had been prepping for such an eventuality. When the fortunes of the nation are at stake, China stands ready to resist, vowing to be there for the long haul and “fight to the very end.”

The country is stronger and more united than it was during Trump’s first term. Increasingly, the Chinese people see the trade war as part of inevitable growing pains and are convinced that the country will emerge more resilient than ever. Although the effects of the tariffs on China’s economy will become sharper, Beijing believes that it can endure the trade war longer than the United States can, and it remains confident that the nation will be able to achieve its projected economic growth of around 5 percent in 2025.

In the U.S., Trump’s tariffs are beginning to bite as well. Consumers and businesses are feeling the pinch of inflation. Meanwhile, China’s export controls on critical minerals are hitting a slew of sectors, including the U.S. defense sector. Tesla, for example, could miss its production plan of 1,000 humanoid robots in 2025 if it fails to secure rare minerals from China. But the worst is yet to come for the United States. Like cancerous cells, the pain will spread gradually.

The U.S. remains highly dependent on China for a large number of commodities. In 2023, China accounted for the majority of smartphones (76 percent), natural graphite (70.3 percent) and portable computers (78 percent). It was also the source of 75 percent of the dolls, tricycles and scooters in 2024.

Trump sees China’s trade surplus with the U.S. as America having the upper hand. Stephen Miran, chair of Trump’s Council of Economic Advisers, even claimed: “We can make stuff at home. We can buy from other countries.” That may be the case in the long run, but for the short term the key is how quickly the U.S. is able to replace Chinese products at comparable prices. As things stand now, a host of products — high-end products in particular — cannot be easily substituted. China is, and will be for a considerable period of time, the only real game in town. So its trade surplus with the U.S. is an actually an advantage, not as Trump believes. As Martin Wolf of the Financial Times pointed out, it is easier for China to cope with its lost demand than for the U.S. to deal with its missing supply.

In 2005, Sara Bongiorni, an American journalist, conducted a yearlong experiment on how her family would fare without Chinese products. Trump is now conducting a similar experiment on all Americans. Very soon he will discover what Bongiorni concluded two decades ago: Finding alternatives for Chinese goods is not just hard but also expensive. And it is sometimes practically impossible. Washington has long been making noise about the risks of relying on China economically, and yet in its rush to tame China it apparently forgot its vulnerability.

With Chinese products largely kept out of the U.S. market by Trump’s steep tariffs, Americans are likely to experience COVID-19-style shortages with a host of products. When inventories are used up, as the CEOs of major U.S. retailers reportedly warned Trump, store shelves will be left empty. Even if alternative sources for some Chinese products are readily available, the costs of the imports will be substantially higher given Trump’s baseline tariff of 10 percent on all imports, up from 2.3 percent in 2024. As a result, while the purses of consumers are hit by inflation, businesses will be forced to cut back their operations or even close outright.

The current trade war is not just one between China and the United States; it pits America against the rest of the world. Trump’s punitive duties amount, in essence, to extortion of other countries. As such, they have caused considerable resentment and indignation globally, alienating U.S. allies and adversaries alike. The longer Trump’s new tariffs stay in place, the more damage they will inflict on U.S. ties with the rest of the world.

Time seems to be on China’s side. While Trump expected that China would be anxious to make a deal in the face of his crushing levies, he actually found it impossible to goad China to the negotiating table. China seems to be in no rush to negotiate an end to the tariff deadlock.

Apart from safeguarding its own rights, China’s retaliatory measures were designed to defend the multilateral trading system and international fairness and justice. Trump’s so-called reciprocal tariffs blatantly violate the most-favored nations principle of the World Trade Organization — the cornerstone of the rules-based international order. They also upend the way in which global trading rules are established, replacing the system of consensus-based decision-making with Trump’s personal wishes and whims.

In fighting Trump’s “liberation day” tariffs with its own levies on the U.S., China has borne the brunt of Trump’s wrath. But saying no to his bullying may have played a critical role in prompting him to pause his promised higher tariffs. An act of justice that won wide support in much of the world, according to Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, China’s pushback provided a huge moral boost for countries struggling to respond to Trump’s overwhelming tariff threat. It encourages them to push back as well on Trump’s demanding terms. As it considers its responsibility and obligation to stand up to Washington’s hegemonic trade policies, China can be expected to hold off on trade talks with Washington even as the Trump administration attempts to coerce other countries into accepting his exorbitant demands.

Another sticking point in the standoff centers on which side should make the first move to de-escalate the crisis. The White House was adamant that the ball is in China’s court. While keeping the door open to trade talks, Beijing has insisted that he who tied the knot should be the first to untie it. Trump impartió una orden al Departamento de Comercio y al Representante de Comercio de Estados Unidos para proceder en esa dirección. La decisión es una amenaza a la seguridad nacional. Trump autorizó al Departamento de Comercio y al Representante de Comercio de Estados Unidos a comenzar el proceso para imponer un arancel del 100 % a todas las películas que ingresen a su país y que hayan sido producidas en el extranjero. Esta medida pone en jaque el desarrollo de la industria cinematográfica dominicana, debido al impacto positivo que han tenido en el sector las grandes producciones extranjeras que se han acogido a los incentivos de la Ley 108-10, promulgada en 2010 por el entonces presidente Leonel Fernández. La industria cinematográfica dominicana generó más de 175 millones de dólares en 2023. En 2021, la titular de la Dirección General de Cine (Dgcine), Marianna Vargas, declaró que, durante la pandemia ocasionada por la COVID-19, el país recibió 152 millones de dólares. Hasta el año 2022 se habían filmado 373 producciones extranjeras.

title: Niño Becerra lanza una grave advertencia a los españoles: "Estamos ante una posible parálisis ecónomica global"
content: La economía española vuelve a estar bajo presión. La ciudadanía observa con creciente inquietud cómo la inflación no da tregua, el precio de los alimentos se dispara y las hipotecas continúan subiendo ...
resumen:
El economista Santiago Niño Becerra advierte sobre una posible parálisis económica global.

Niño Becerra, catedrático de Estructura Económica en la Universitat Ramón Llull, ha analizado la situación mundial.

Niño Becerra ha mostrado un gráfico del índice S&P 500, desde los mínimos de la crisis del año 2008 (735 puntos) hasta los máximos actuales, que en 2025 se sitúan en los 6.101 puntos.

Niño Becerra explicó que una caída del 10% no es preocupante, pero una caída del 80% sí lo sería.

Niño Becerra añadió que el crecimiento actual es puro efecto de la especulación alimentada por la inyección masiva de liquidez por parte de los bancos centrales en los años 2009, 2012, 2018 y durante la pandemia.

Niño Becerra advirtió que, si las tensiones comerciales entre China y EE.UU. continúan escalando, podríamos enfrentar un escenario comparable al que se vivió durante el confinamiento mundial en 2020.

Niño Becerra detalló que, de seguir con más aranceles y represalias, podríamos vivir este verano una parálisis económica global, una nueva 'situación Covid'.

Niño Becerra destacó que China lleva ventaja en esta guerra comercial con Estados Unidos porque tiene más activos, ha aprendido del colonialismo económico de EE.UU. y está invirtiendo estratégicamente en África y Sudamérica.

title: Anuncio de Trump sobre aranceles a películas extranjeras afecta también a RD
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció un arancel del 100 % a todas las películas producidas en el extranjero.
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció un arancel del 100 % a todas las películas producidas en el extranjero, con el objetivo de revivir la industria cinematográfica nacional. La medida forma parte de una estrategia para frenar lo que él considera la “devastación” de Hollywood por los incentivos que otros países ofrecen a cineastas estadounidenses. Trump exclamó: “¡Queremos cine hecho en Estados Unidos, otra vez!”, al tiempo que advirtió sobre la fuga de producciones hacia otros territorios con políticas fiscales más favorables.

El anuncio genera preocupación para países que se han consolidado como destinos claves para el cine internacional, entre ellos la República Dominicana.

La República Dominicana se ha posicionado como un destino predilecto para la filmación de producciones extranjeras, gracias a sus incentivos fiscales, paisajes diversos y mano de obra calificada. La Ley de Cine No. 108-10 permite a las producciones internacionales acceder a un crédito fiscal transferible del 25 % sobre los gastos realizados en el país, lo que ha atraído a numerosos estudios estadounidenses. En 2023 se rodaron en el país más de 120 producciones, 45 de ellas extranjeras, lo que representó un impacto económico superior a los RD$10,000 millones. Películas como The Lost City o Old de M. Night Shyamalan, han elegido suelo dominicano para sus rodajes en los últimos años.

La nueva medida de Trump podría alterar este escenario favorable. Un arancel del 100 % sobre las películas filmadas fuera de EE.UU. implica un aumento significativo en los costos de distribución para los estudios que elijan filmar en el extranjero. Muchos productores podrían optar por rodar dentro del territorio estadounidense. Para la República Dominicana, esto se traduciría en una reducción de las producciones internacionales que eligen al país como locación, afectando directamente a múltiples sectores. Se vería comprometido el ingreso de divisas por servicios cinematográficos, y el empleo generado en áreas como logística, construcción, hospedaje, transporte y catering. Además, la medida amenaza con frenar el desarrollo técnico y profesional del talento local.

Otros países latinoamericanos, como México y Colombia, están fortaleciendo sus propios sistemas de incentivos para atraer inversiones cinematográficas. Con los aranceles en juego, la competencia se intensifica, y la República Dominicana podría perder atractivo ante destinos que ofrezcan mayores ventajas fiscales o logísticas.

title: Trump’s tariffs could spell disaster for Arkansas soybean farmers already struggling to stay afloat
content: The million dollar question is where are Arkansas soybeans going to go if farmers are locked out of Chinese markets?
resumen: Trump’s tariffs could spell disaster for Arkansas soybean farmers already struggling to stay afloat. President Trump has placed temporary pauses on many of the “Liberation Day” tariffs the administration rolled out on April 2, but the United States has kept in place a 145% tariff on most Chinese imports. China has retaliated with tariffs that include a 135% levy on soybeans, one of the country’s largest imports from the U.S. and one of Arkansas’s main crops. Brandy Caroll, an Arkansas Farm Bureau economist, said that much of our soybean exports go to China for animal feed. Farmers are also affected by U.S. tariffs on imports, which could raise prices for inputs “on everything from fertilizers to drones,” Caroll said. Margins could get tighter as it becomes more difficult for farmers to cash flow this year. Arkansas’s soybean exports topped $1 billion globally in 2023, and soybean meal sales were $288 million, according to data from the U.S. Trade Representative. Rice exports weren’t far behind at $868 million. In 2023, Arkansas farmers harvested 2.9 million acres of soybeans and 1.4 million acres of rice, and Arkansas continues to be the largest rice producer in the country. The U.S.-China Business Council estimated in 2023 that out of $953 million in exports to China from Arkansas, $613 million was from grains and oilseeds, a category that includes soybeans. Almost all of that value — $556 million — was produced in Arkansas’s 1st Congressional District, represented by Republican Rick Crawford, which includes most of the Arkansas Delta. Over the last two years, Arkansas farmers have seen their incomes decline dramatically as the prices of crops like soybeans and corn have plummeted and costs have risen. The University of Missouri, in collaboration with the University of Arkansas, released a study in April 2024 showing total Arkansas farm income dropped from $3.4 billion in 2023 to $2.9 billion in 2024. The number of farms in the state keeps dropping too, as farmers leave the business due to financial pressures. Hallie Shoffner, a sixth-generation rice and soybean farmer near Newport, said that she ran six different spreadsheets to see if she could cash flow, and not one projected anything other than a loss this year. Shoffner announced a couple months ago that she would be closing her family farm, which had been in operation for over 150 years. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has projected farm income will increase in 2025, largely driven by higher profits from livestock, according to Carroll. Delta farmers were expecting another hard year ahead, even before the tariffs kicked in. Ryan Loy, a University of Arkansas Division of Agriculture agricultural economist, examined the effects of a theoretical Chinese tariff of just 10% on U.S. soybeans in 2025 — far less than the rate China has actually imposed on American imports — based on the amount of American soybeans they imported in 2024. His conservative analysis found that it would cost Chinese businesses $1.2 billion in taxes. China is by far the largest importer of American soybeans. U.S. farmers exported $12.4 billion worth of soybeans to China in 2024, according to data from the USDA Foreign Agricultural Service. The next largest trading partner for soybeans was the European Union at $2.43 billion. The EU initially floated a 25% reciprocal tariff on goods from the U.S., including soybeans, but suspended the tax when Trump also suspended most of his proposed tariffs. In 2016, U.S. soybean exports to China were worth $14.2 billion. They plummeted over the next two years and in 2018 bottomed out at just $3.12 billion as China charged higher tariffs. Since 2018, Brazil has rapidly outpaced U.S. farmers in soybean exports to China, according to a report from CNN Business. China bought $31 billion worth of soybeans from Brazil in 2024. By contrast, China purchased only $12.8 billion worth of soybeans from American farmers the same year, according to the USDA. Shoffner’s farm started growing soybeans in 2016. Loy said that Brazil can undercut us six to one on soybean prices and still make money. During the last trade war, the Trump administration bailed out farmers for their economic losses to the tune of $61 billion from authorized relief payments between 2018 and 2020.

title: Trump’s tariffs have launched global trade wars. Here’s a timeline of how we got here
content: Long-threatened tariffs from U.S. President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad — all while on-again, off-again new levies continue to escalate uncertainty.
resumen:
**NEW YORK (AP)** — Long-threatened tariffs from U.S. President Donald Trump have plunged the country into trade wars abroad — all while on-again, off-again new levies continue to escalate uncertainty.

Trump launched a trade war during his first term, taking particular aim at China by putting taxes on most of its goods. Beijing responded with its own retaliatory tariffs on a range of U.S. products. Trump also used the threat of more tariffs to force Canada and Mexico to renegotiate a North American trade pact, called the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, in 2020.

When President Joe Biden took office, he preserved most of the tariffs Trump previously enacted against China, in addition to imposing some new restrictions.

Economists stress there could be greater consequences on businesses and economies worldwide under Trump’s more sweeping tariffs this time around — and that higher prices will likely leave consumers footing the bill. There’s also been a sense of whiplash from Trump’s back-and-forth tariff threats and responding retaliation seen over the last few months.

**Timeline:**

*   **January 20:** Trump is sworn into office. He promises to “tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens.” He reiterates plans to create an agency called the External Revenue Service, which has yet to be established. Trump says he expects to put 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting on Feb. 1, while declining to immediately flesh out plans for taxing Chinese imports.
*   **January 26:** Trump threatens 25% tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro’s rejects two U.S. military aircraft carrying migrants to the country. Petro announces a retaliatory 25% increase in Colombian tariffs on U.S. goods. Colombia later reversed its decision and accepted the flights carrying migrants. The two countries soon signaled a halt in the trade dispute.
*   **February 1:** Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada and China — 10% on all imports from China and 25% on imports from Mexico and Canada starting Feb. 4. Trump invoked this power by declaring a national emergency. The action prompts swift outrage from all three countries, with promises of retaliatory measures.
*   **February 3:** Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada.
*   **February 4:** Trump’s new 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports to the U.S. still go into effect. China retaliates the same day by announcing a flurry of countermeasures, including sweeping new duties on a variety of American goods and an anti-monopoly investigation into Google. China’s 15% tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products, and a 10% levy on crude oil, agricultural machinery and large-engine cars imported from the U.S., take effect Feb. 10.
*   **February 10:** Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12. He removes the exemptions from his 2018 tariffs on steel, meaning that all steel imports will be taxed at a minimum of 25%, and also raises his 2018 aluminum tariffs from 10% to 25%.
*   **February 13:** Trump announces a plan for “reciprocal” tariffs — promising to increase U.S. tariffs to match the tax rates that countries worldwide charge on imports “for purposes of fairness.”
*   **February 25:** Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether a tariff on imported copper is needed to protect national security.
*   **March 1:** Trump signs an additional executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether tariffs on lumber and timber are also needed to protect national security.
*   **March 4:** Trump’s 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10% on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20%. All three countries promise retaliatory measures. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces tariffs on more than $100 billion of American goods over the course of 21 days. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum says her country would respond with its own retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods. China imposes tariffs of up to 15% on a wide array of key U.S. farm exports, set to take effect March 10. It also expands the number of U.S. companies subject to export controls and other restrictions by about two dozen.
*   **March 5:** Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for U.S. automakers.
*   **March 6:** Trump postpones 25% tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month.
*   **March 10:** China’s retaliatory 15% tariffs on key American farm products — including chicken, pork, soybeans and beef — take effect. Goods already in transit are set to be exempt through April 12.
*   **March 12:** Trump’s new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. Both metals are now taxed at 25% across the board. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action promising new duties on U.S. industrial and farm products. The measures will cover goods from the United States worth some 26 billion euros ($28 billion). Canada announces plans to impose more retaliatory tariffs worth Canadian $29.8 billion ($20.7 billion) on U.S. imports, set to go into effect March 13.
*   **March 13:** Trump threatens a 200% tariff on European wine, Champagne and spirits if the European Union goes forward with its previously-announced plans for a 50% tariff on American whiskey.
*   **March 24:** Trump says he will place a 25% tariff on all imports from any country that buys oil or gas from Venezuela, in addition to imposing new tariffs on the South American country itself, starting April 2.
*   **March 26:** Trump says he is placing 25% tariffs on auto imports. These auto imports will start being collected April 3 — beginning with taxes on fully-imported cars. The tariffs are set to then expand to applicable auto parts in the following weeks, through May 3.
*   **April 2:** Trump announces his long-promised “reciprocal” tariffs — declaring a 10% baseline tax on imports across the board starting April 5, as well as higher rates for dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the U.S. to take effect April 9. Among those steeper levies, Trump says the U.S. will now charge a 34% tax on imports from China, a 20% tax on imports from the European Union, 25% on South Korea, 24% on Japan and 32% on Taiwan

title: Skechers cambia de dueño, ¿quién la comprará y por cuánto?
content: La empresa de calzado Skechers será adquirida por más de 9 mil millones de dólares y será privatizada por la firma de inversión 3G Capital.
resumen: Skechers será adquirida por más de 9 mil millones de dólares y será privatizada por la firma de inversión 3G Capital. El acuerdo se produce en medio de la creciente incertidumbre sobre cómo afectarán los aranceles impuestos por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump a los productos extranjeros a las empresas que fabrican sus productos en el extranjero, especialmente en China. La oferta de 63 dólares por acción representa una prima del 30% sobre el precio promedio ponderado por volumen de las acciones de Skechers en 15 días. El acuerdo fue aprobado por unanimidad por la junta directiva de Skechers. Las acciones de Skechers subieron casi un 25% este lunes, hasta los 61,56 dólares. Skechers afirmó que aproximadamente dos tercios de sus ingresos provienen de ventas fuera de EE. UU., y China representa el 15% de los ingresos de la compañía, según la firma de datos FactSet. El acuerdo llega en un momento delicado con los continuos anuncios arancelarios intermitentes de Trump. Skechers no emitió pronósticos cuando publicó sus resultados del primer trimestre en abril. El director financiero, John Vandemore, declaró a los inversores que “el entorno actual es simplemente demasiado dinámico como para planificar resultados con una garantía razonable de éxito”. Los ejecutivos también afirmaron que buscarían minimizar el envío de productos a EE. UU. desde “lugares de alto costo”, incluyendo el impacto de los aranceles. Skechers cuenta con alrededor de 5.300 tiendas minoristas en todo el mundo, de las cuales aproximadamente 1.800 son propiedad de la compañía. Se espera que el acuerdo con 3G Capital se cierre en el tercer trimestre de este año. title: In latest Fed survey of businesses, Trump fails miserably
content: The latest Fed survey comes as Trump continues to rail against Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell for refusing to lower interest rates.
resumen: President Donald Trump’s plan to bring manufacturing back to the United States through tariffs appears to have hit a wall. The latest Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas survey showed that companies are passing on the cost of goods and services to consumers instead of switching production to the U.S. Just 11% of manufacturing firms say they are relocating to the U.S. while just 3% of service firms said the same as a result of the tariffs, according to Apollo Chief Economist Torsten Sløk. 76% of manufacturing firms and 47% of service firms are planning to pass the cost of tariffs onto the consumer, according to the data. Just 37% of manufacturing firms and 26% of service firms said they are looking for domestic suppliers as a result of the tariffs. About half of manufacturing firms said they will absorb the cost of tariffs internally while 42% of service firms said the same. The Fed will almost certainly leave its key rate unchanged at about 4.3% when it meets Tuesday and Wednesday. Trump said on the social media platform Truth Social that there is “NO INFLATION” and claimed that grocery and egg prices have fallen, and that gas has dropped to $1.98 a gallon. Grocery prices have jumped 0.5% in two of the past three months and are up 2.4% from a year ago. Gas costs are down 10% from a year ago. AAA says gas prices nationwide average $3.18 a gallon. In the first three months of the year inflation was 3.6%, according to the Fed’s preferred gauge, well above its 2% target.

title: A chance to reshape a narrative of Australia’s place in the world
content: Australia's incumbent Labor Party government achieved a landslide victory at the 2025 federal election — the US alliance will be Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's first challenge.
resumen: In the 2025 federal election, Australia's incumbent Labor Party government, led by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, achieved a landslide victory over the conservative Liberal-National opposition coalition. The defeat highlighted Australian voters' aversion to the Trump-like populism espoused by opposition leader Peter Dutton, especially after the global repercussions from the United States' Liberation Day tariffs. Increasing scepticism about US reliability as an alliance partner now challenges the Labor Party to reframe its regional partnerships and shift away from an increasingly untenable US alliance orthodoxy. Australians have lost more than 10 years of real wage growth since the last election [in 2022]. Real household disposable income per capita grew 8.9 per cent across the OECD from the end of the 2018–19 financial year through to the same time in 2024. In Australia, it fell 1.4 per cent. Dutton and his colleagues integrated Trump-like themes into their election campaign. The global fallout from Liberation Day happened to coincide with the April Australian campaign period. Dutton follows in the footsteps of Canadian conservative leader Pierre Poilievre in the humiliation of losing his own parliamentary seat amid an unexpectedly large pro-government swing. The spectre of Trump-style populism helped rescue Albanese’s Labor Party government from the threat of defeat. Washington’s new normal, combined with their emphatic victory, now presents the prime minister and his foreign minister, Penny Wong, the opportunity and the responsibility to begin shifting the terms of the political debate around Australian foreign policy now that the conservative guardians of an increasingly untenable pro-US orthodoxy are politically marginalised. The partnerships that Australia will increasingly need to defend its core interests — free trade, multilateralism, and international law — will more often be found among the middle powers in the region, and globally, than in a revisionist United States. Polling shows Australians remain broadly supportive of the US alliance but also increasingly sceptical of US reliability as an alliance partner. Australians continue to view the relationship as important, even as majorities of both Labor and Coalition voters believe Australia can no longer depend so largely on the United States for its security needs. The government has to be ready to absorb criticism from the US alliance cultists in the opposition and a commentariat who are prone to react hysterically to any suggestion that Australian and US agendas may diverge — or that Australia and China might share some important overlapping interests in areas like trade or climate.

title: Seven foreign policy challenges facing Mark Carney that aren’t about Trump
content: A looming G7 summit and NATO meeting, dealing with soured relations with both China and India, expanding British trade ties, foreign aid and instability in the Middle East are all on the PM's agenda.
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney has many foreign policy issues on his plate.

In six weeks, Carney will welcome his leading counterparts to Kananaskis, Alta., for the Group of Seven leaders’ summit. Trump is invited to attend, as are the leaders of France, Germany, Japan, the U.K. and Italy, as well as the European Union. When Canada last hosted a G7 summit in 2018, Trump refused to sign the closing communiqué, stormed off early and called Carney’s predecessor Justin Trudeau “very dishonest and weak” in a spat over steel and aluminum tariffs. Ottawa is trying to keep Washington engaged in the G7. Leaders at the summit are expected to discuss “shadow fleets” — vessels smuggling sanctioned goods — the recent rash of sabotage attacks on undersea cables, illegal fishing and biodiversity loss. Canada must also decide which countries and institutions it will welcome as guests; South Africa is hosting the G20 summit in November and could be invited to Kananaskis. Carney already has invited Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Carney is widely expected to attend the annual summit of the NATO military alliance, which starts June 24 in the Netherlands. Canada has never met the NATO defence spending guideline — 2 per cent of gross domestic product — since the alliance agreed upon that goal in 2006. The meeting also comes amid fears that Russia will acquire more territory in Ukraine and invade other countries like Latvia, where Canadian troops are serving as part of a mission aimed at deterring Russian aggression. The European Union is leading an effort to boost defence spending and military industries in Europe, to make the continent less reliant on the U.S. Carney has said he wants to be part of this project, called ReArm Europe.

During the campaign, Carney described China as “the biggest security threat to Canada,” citing Beijing’s tacit support for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, foreign interference and the Arctic. Beijing has imposed tariffs in retaliation for Canada following the U.S. in restricting Chinese electric vehicles and steel. While China is Canada’s second-largest trading partner and says it can collaborate in areas like clean energy, Carney has signalled caution.

In late 2022, the Liberals made India a focus of their Indo-Pacific strategy. Within months, Trudeau accused India of involvement in Nijjar’s death. Relations have been strained ever since, with the RCMP saying it has evidence that New Delhi is behind numerous crimes targeting Sikh-Canadians. Carney said during the election campaign he wants to pursue trade with India, adding it could play an outsized role in ending the trade wars. The government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi has long been aligned with Canada’s Conservatives, though Modi was quick to congratulate Carney on his election win.

Canada and the U.K. have been operating under a pared-down trade agreement since Brexit and talks on a full agreement have been suspended, largely over Canada’s reluctance to open up its dairy sector and Britain’s distaste for hormone-treated beef. Canada’s envoy to London Ralph Goodale told Politico recently that trade talks are unlikely to advance if Britain doesn’t drop “unscientific” limits on beef or resolve the “Brexit screw-up” of failing to negotiate its own cheese import quota for Canada when it left the European Union.

Promising to buck the trend of Western countries scaling back on foreign aid, Carney has vowed not to lower Canada’s aid spending or development funding. It’s not clear what Carney’s approach to foreign aid might look like. Southeast Asian leaders, meanwhile, are wondering whether Carney will follow Trudeau’s example by attending the annual summit of the ASEAN bloc, which declared Canada a strategic partner in 2023.

Carney is widely expected to follow Trudeau’s approach to the Israel-Hamas war, a policy Jewish, Muslim and Arab groups have all widely criticized as being vague. The prime minister recently joined peers in criticizing Israel for blocking aid to Palestinians in Gaza. Carney said during the campaign that Canada must call out Iran for destabilizing the Middle East through proxies like Hamas.

title: Rich and poor in Germany: The gulf continues to widen
content: A tiny minority of around 0.6 per cent of the population In Germany now owns 45 percent of total wealth in Germany. More and more, the situation is reminiscent of the conditions before the French ...
resumen:
According to the Paritätische Poverty Report, 13 million people in Germany live below the poverty line. The proportion of poor people in the population rose last year by 1.1 percent to 15.5 percent. More than one in five people in Germany is now at risk of poverty.

According to a new Oxfam report, CEO salaries worldwide have risen by 50 percent in five years, 56 times more than the average wages of employees. In Germany, the median salary of top managers has risen to 4.4 million euros—30 times higher than the average wages of all employees.

A tiny minority of around 0.6 percent of the population now owns 45 percent of total wealth in Germany.

The unemployed are particularly affected by poverty, with over 60 percent considered poor according to the poverty report.

In the 18 to 25-year-old age group, almost one in four people (24.8 percent) are considered poor, with girls and women (26.9 percent) particularly affected.

Almost one in five (19.4 percent) aged 65 and over are affected by poverty. Pensioners account for more than a quarter of all poor people in Germany, with over 21 percent of all women over the age of 65 considered poor.

Single people (29 percent) and single parents (27 percent) stand out in particular.

Around 30 percent of people without German citizenship are considered poor.

People with disabilities and chronic illnesses are also very often poor.

Bremen (25.9 percent) and Saxony-Anhalt (22.3 percent) are particularly affected by poverty. North Rhine-Westphalia has a poverty rate of 17.4 percent, while some cities in the Ruhr area—Duisburg (28.5 percent), Essen (29.4 percent), Dortmund (28.2 percent) and Gelsenkirchen (as high as 37.9 percent)—are well above this figure.

In 2021, the poverty rate was reduced by 27.7 percentage points to 16 percent through state redistribution. In 2024, social benefits only reduced it by 25.1 percentage points to 15.5 percent.

The consumer price index rose by almost 20 percent (to 119) between 2020 (=100) and 2024. In 2020, real wages fell by 1.2 percent and in 2022 by as much as 4 percent.

The poverty line is currently set at €1,381 per month for single people; for a family of four with two children (under 14), it is €2,900. 5.2 million people have to live in considerable material deprivation, including around 1.1 million minors and young people and 1.2 million full-time workers.

The proportion of those in employment is 19.9 percent of the total number of poor people in Germany. More than two and a half million people belong to this category of working poor.

In 2020, the poor had an average monthly income of 981 euros. In 2024, the average was 1,099 euros, which, adjusted for inflation, corresponds to a median income of 921 euros.

CEO salaries have risen 56 times as much as the real wages of dependent employees over the last five years. Worldwide, the median average salary of CEOs has risen by 50 percent and amounted to no less than 4.3 million US dollars in 2024.

56 CEOs from Germany received more than one million US dollars last year, including basic salary, bonuses and stock options. Their median salary in 2024 was 4.4 million euros, 21 percent higher than in 2019. In contrast, the real wages of workers and employees rose by only 0.7 percent over the same period, 30 times less.
